                                OPERATION AND PROGRAM SUMMARY
                                            REPUBLIC OF RWANDA
                           FIFTH POVERTY REDUCTION SUPPORT GRANT
Borrower               Republic of Rwanda
Implementing Agency    Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning
Financing Data         Grant amount of SDR 53 million (US $80 million equivalent)
Operation Type         Programmatic (2nd of 3), single-tranche
Main Policy Areas      ·   Investment and business climate
                           o    Human capital and skills development
                           o    Infrastructure ­ policy environment and investment
                           o    Agriculture productivity
                           o    Financial sector development
                       ·   Public expenditure and financial management
Key Outcome            ·   Transition from basic education (TC) to upper secondary education
Indicators             ·   Percent of employees satisfied with performance of TVET
                       ·   Number of households and firms with access to electricity
                       ·   MW of electricity generated
                       ·   Percent of classified District Road Network in Good Condition
                       ·   Percent of water resources complying with water quality standards certified by the Rwanda
                           Bureau of Standards
                       ·   Arable land protected against soil erosion
                       ·   Percent of farmers using improved methods ­ Chemical and organic fertilizer
                       ·   Credit to the private sector (as share of GDP)
                       ·   Percent of Districts achieving minimum of 80 percent of their development targets


Program Development  The proposed operation will contribute to the strategic outcomes outlined in the CAS by focusing
Objective(s) and     support on two EDPRS flagship programs ­ Growth for Jobs and Exports, and Governance Support
Contribution to CAS  to these two flagship areas will be aimed at: (i) raising agricultural production in a sustainable
                       manner; (ii) increasing access to infrastructure services; (iii) strengthening the framework for post-
                       basic education, with the aim of building a skilled workforce and promoting science and technology;
                     (iv) deepening the financial sector including capacity building measures to facilitate increased
                       access to finance by micro-enterprises; and (v) strengthening the management of public resources at
                       the central and local levels. The operation complements the sector budget support operation being
                       developed to support continued reforms in health and the implementation of the Village Umurenge
                     Program (VUP).       PRSG-5 preparation capitalizes on the much improved, fully government-led
                     donor coordination, a direct result of the budget support program in Rwanda. It draws from the
                     recently completed Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF) for monitoring the
                     EDPRS, to reduce the transaction costs of Government reporting to donors on the use of aid funds.
Risks and Risks      The main risks to the program arise from two areas: (i) continued instability in the Great Lakes sub-
Mitigation           region and the effects on economic stability and donor support; (ii) continued global economic
                     slowdown. Though international and regional efforts to mitigate instability in the Great Lakes sub-
                     region are continuing there is a substantial risk of flare ups in the eastern Congo. The Bank supports
                     efforts aimed at fostering peace and security between Rwanda and its neighbors.              Internally
                     Rwanda's security and political situation remains stable. Predictability of donor financing, is an
                     issue, though alignment of donor disbursements with the GoR's budget cycle has improved. Risks
                     associated with capacity weaknesses in the country's fiduciary framework, will be addressed through
                     the PFM Action Plan. The second PRSG series (covering PRSG-4 to PRSG-6), supports the GoR's
                       capacity building efforts in the above areas. There is also a downside risk to Rwanda's economic
                       growth should the global slowdown persist. The immediate risk would arise from a likely increase
                       in the external account deficit from potential reductions in the commitments of budget support
                       donors. The Bank will closely monitor the situation and could provide supplemental financing as
                       needed. Government will continue its policy of identifying areas for contingent spending should
                       more external resources become available. It will also continue to protect priority spending from
                       any reductions in overall spending. Finally, it will continue with measures to expand the tax base
                       and improve the efficiency of the tax system.
Project ID Number    P106083




                                                            v


                         INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION
                                     PROGRAM DOCUMENT FOR A
            PROPOSED FIFTH POVERTY REDUCTION SUPPORT GRANT (PRSG-5)
                                   TO THE REPUBLIC OF RWANDA


                                          I. INTRODUCTION


1.      The proposed Fifth Poverty Reduction Support Grant (PRSG-5) continues to support the
Government of Rwanda as it implements measures to foster broad based growth in the context of
enhanced decentralization reforms. PRSG-5 is the second operation in the second series of PRSGs
(beginning with PRSG-4). It forms an integral part of the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS),
approved by the Board of Executive Directors on September 26, 2008 in support of the Government's
Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EDPRS). The EDPRS covers the period 2008-
2012 and takes stock of a decade of achievements in rehabilitation and reconstruction, presenting a
strategy focused on accelerating growth and human development, with emphasis on decentralization, and
a greater role for the private sector. The EDPRS priorities are articulated through three flagship programs:
Sustainable Growth for Jobs and Exports; Vision 2020 Umurenge, focused on community development;
and Governance.

2.      The EDPRS highlights the importance of enhanced decentralization to provide equitable,
efficient, and effective pro-poor service delivery while promoting local development in an
environment of good governance. The Government's strategy reflects its commitment to transform the
society and overcome the causes and consequences of the genocide which are seen to have been due to
poor governance and a lack of local voice and empowerment. This provides the rationale for GoR's
model of democratization, grounded in a decentralized administration to promote peace and
reconciliation, with the aim of facilitating increased participation of local communities in defining their
own development.

3.      In line with the EDPRS, the second PRSG series supports measures to generate sustained
economic growth, emphasizing improved delivery of economic and infrastructure services. The
PRSG series focuses on the Growth for Jobs and Exports, and Governance, pillars of the EDPRS, and is
centered on 5 priority areas: (i) raising agricultural production in a sustainable manner; (ii) improving
access to and quality of key economic infrastructure services; (iii) strengthening the framework for post-
basic education, with the aim of building a skilled workforce and promoting science and technology; (iv)
deepening and widening the financial sector; (v) strengthening management of public resources at the
central and local levels.

4.      The second PRSG series, starting with PRSG-4, complements the Community Living
Standards Grant (CLSG) currently under preparation.             The CLSG is a sector development policy
grant concentrated on Government efforts to strengthen service delivery to the poorest and most
vulnerable. It defines a 3-year program of support to the Vision 2020 Umurenge Program (VUP) with a
focus on the social protection and health sectors. The program will strengthen implementation of public
works employment, cash transfer to the poor and landless, and delivery of high impact health and
nutrition interventions at the community level.

5.      PRSG-5 focuses on reforms to ease human capital and infrastructure constraints to growth,
foster fiscal decentralization, and strengthen the results orientation of the MTEF and the budget
process. Continued capacity support to enable implementation of reforms to financial management and
the budget and procurement frameworks is also envisioned.           Overall, the operation will emphasize




                                                   1

support for reforms that promote increased spending efficiency, to lay the foundation for increased
absorption and effectiveness of higher aid inflows.

6.       PRSG-5 is the first in the PRSG series to be fully aligned with the Common Performance
Assessment Framework. PRSG-4 was prepared as a transition operation that allowed sufficient space
and time for consultation in preparing the Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF). This
approach, discussed and endorsed by Government and donors, enabled the Bank to respond in a timely
manner to the GoR's urgent need for resources. PRSG-4 actions were therefore developed in the context
of initial consultations during preparation of the CPAF, drawing from the key areas of the EDPRS and the
related EDPRS policy matrix.

7.       The CPAF has been developed under the leadership of the Government of Rwanda (GoR)
and in close collaboration with donors and other development partners. The policy measures and
indicators have been prioritized based on consultation and discussions held both through the sector
reviews and sector working groups, as well as the Joint Budget Support Group. Prior actions and triggers
for PRSG-5 are taken directly from the CPAF and reflect the broad based consultation undertaken in-
country in its preparation. However, all stakeholders also recognize the need to strengthen the policy
actions included in the CPAF. The Bank team will continue to work with other donors to support
Government in refining the policy actions to ensure these are outcome oriented and appropriately tied to
the relevant indicators. In that regard, the updated Partnership Framework includes agreed guidelines for
updates to the CPAF, as the policy context evolves. This will also enable the strengthening of policy
actions in the outer years. Box 3 in section IV of this program document summarizes the process used to
develop the CPAF.

8.       The remainder of this program document outlines the components of the proposed
operation.    Discussion of the country context in Section II focuses on economic developments in
realizing key outcomes targeted by the EDPRS. Section III outlines the GoR's program followed by the
discussion of the Bank's support to the GoR's strategy in section IV. Section V describes the areas to be
supported under PRSG-5. Section VI concludes with an overview of the implementation arrangements,
benefits and risks of the proposed operation.


                                     II.    COUNTRY CONTEXT


                                A.   RECENT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENTS

Recent Growth Performance


9.       Rwanda's economy has remained resilient over the last five years, with GDP estimated in
2008 to be US $4.2 billion in nominal terms, enabling the country to sustain macroeconomic
stability despite exogenous shocks that affected agricultural productivity. Estimates are that the
economy grew by 8.5 percent in 2008, fueled, in large part, by a strong recovery in agriculture, which
grew by nearly 15 percent, with the ongoing expansion of the crop intensification program (CIP). This
contrasts with the 7.9 percent growth that occurred in 2007 which was driven by growth in the services
and manufacturing sectors as agricultural output expanded by just less than 1 percent in 2007 due mainly
to poor weather conditions. In 2008, the services and industrial sectors, as well as private consumption,
continued to expand but at a slower pace (see Table 1), while growth in investment remained rapid. To
date, the recent global economic slowdown, which has brought down commodity prices has not affected
overall growth due to the small share of exports in GDP. Nevertheless, short-term risks to economic
growth may have increased due to likely effects of the slowdown on FDI, remittances, and external
finance.



                                                    2

10.       Rwanda appears to have fully exhausted the growth effects of the post-conflict
reconstruction period; sustained growth over the short-term will depend heavily on the agricultural
sector. Average real GDP growth rates showed a considerable slow-down from an annual rate of about
10.5 percent attained over 1996-02 ­ the first few years following the conflict--to 5.6 percent over the
period 2003-2007. Average growth over this period is below the annual minimum of 8 percent needed to
meet the GoR's poverty reduction target for the MDG.1 The strong performance of agriculture in 2008
helped raise average annual growth to 6.1 percent over the period 2003-08, demonstrating that raising
agricultural productivity is critical for attaining higher growth and reducing poverty. This is an area that
needs to be prioritized over the short-term, to meet the broad based growth and poverty reduction targets,
given that over 80 percent of the population is employed by the agriculture sector.

11.       Global increases in fuel prices through September 2008 and the subsequent economic slow
down have caused further challenges to achieving growth targets. In a context where external shocks
and structural constraints have led to declining growth in the agricultural sector, ongoing developments in
global commodity markets have severely affected the country's level of competitiveness and
consequently its ability to sustain growth. As a land-locked country in which transport costs represent as
high as 40 percent of export and import values, Rwanda is particularly vulnerable to global increases in
fuel costs. In 2008, the higher cost of fuel which translated to higher transport costs had a significant
impact on domestic food and fertilizer prices. The higher fertilizer prices posed a risk to the
Government's program to strengthen agricultural productivity, which was mitigated through the
supplemental financing to PRSG-4.

12.       Higher fuel and food prices contributed to an increase in inflation from 9.1 percent in 2007
to an estimated level of 15 percent by end-2008. Average inflation increased slightly from 8.9 to 9.1
percent between 2006 and 2007 despite higher food and energy prices due in part to GoR's consistently
prudent macroeconomic management. However, during 2007, core inflation ­ i.e excluding energy and
food prices ­ incurred strong upward pressure resulting in an estimate of 9.7 percent annual growth,
mostly due to one-off tariff increases in education, health and water and the rise in housing costs of
almost 50 percent during the year. By end-2008, annual average inflation is estimated to have increased
sharply partly as a result of high international commodity prices and domestic demand pressures.
Pressures on prices are expected to ease in 2009 as import prices for fuel and food decline.

                                             Table 1: GDP Growth, 2003-08

                                                       (% per annum)
                                                                                                             % GDP
                                                                                                         Est. (nominal)
                                 1996-02    2003-07     2003    2004       2005     2006     2007       2008    2007


                                                                Supply Side
 GDP Growth                         10.5        5.6      0.3      5.3       7.2      7.3        7.9      8.5   100.0
 Agriculture                        10.2        0.4     -4.7      0.1       4.8      1.1        0.7     14.8    35.6
 Industry                            7.9        8.9      3.0     12.8       7.5     10.9      10.2       8.0    14.2
 Services                           10.6        9.0      4.5      7.9       9.1     10.9      12.8       6.0    50.2


                                                                Demand Side
 GDP Growth                         10.5        5.6      0.3      5.3       7.2      7.3        7.9      8.5   100.0
 Consumption                         9.4        5.6      0.0      3.6       7.1      9.1        8.3      8.7    97.0
   Private                           9.1        6.0     -1.7      5.7       7.0      9.4        9.5      9.0    86.3
 Investment                          8.8       17.7     10.3     14.9      26.4     12.2      24.7      19.8    21.0
 Exports                            16.7        7.9     -1.8     17.4       8.9      7.9        7.0      3.4    9.7
 Imports                             4.4       15.1      4.2      4.9      22.1     22.7      21.8      16.7    27.7


Source: IMF and World Bank Staff estimates


1
  Estimates based on household surveys suggest that modest reductions in the incidence of poverty were achieved from
60.percent to 56.9 percent between 2000/01 and 2005/06.




                                                         3

External Balance

13.      Import growth exceeded the increase in exports, leading to a substantial worsening of the
trade balance in 2007 and 2008 (see Table 2). In 2007, exports increased by 20.1 percent (f.o.b., US
Dollar terms), mainly due to an expansion of the volume of mining exports and the commodity price
boom. Traditional exports, on the other hand, performed poorly, with the value of coffee exports
contracting by almost 40 percent, mainly due to adverse weather conditions and the slight decline in the
value of tea exports. Growing imports of capital goods as well as intermediate goods for infrastructure
projects in line with higher public capital spending were the main contributors to the large increase of
imports (30.2 percent in US Dollar terms, f.o.b.). The higher fuel prices negatively impacted the current
account balance in 2007, but the effect was mitigated by a gradual reduction of import tariffs and excise
taxes. The surge in food prices did not affect the external balance negatively in 2007, but the pass-
through was stronger in 2008 compared to 2007, because of relatively higher world prices. Inflation
targets have been revised upwards and preliminary estimates suggest that rising fuel and food prices
added 1.6 percent of GDP to the current account deficit in 2008 (see Box 1 for the likely effects, over the
next year or two, of the global economic slow down).

                                           Table 2: Balance of Payments

                                      (U.S. Dollar millions)    2004    2005     2006       2007      2008
Exports, f.o.b.                                                  97.9   126.0    147.3     176.8     221.7
Imports, f.o.b.                                                 275.9   353.7    446.4     581.2     836.5
Trade balance                                                  -178.0  -227.6   -299.1    -404.4    -614.8
Services (net)                                                 -137.1  -166.5   -206.4    -207.6    -282.3
Current transfers (net)                                         312.5   395.2    323.9     461.3     617.3
Current account balance (incl. official transfers)              -36.7   -26.6   -210.3    -167.9    -303.5
Capital and financial account balance                           119.9   137.9    293.3     275.8     342.8
Overall balance                                                  98.8   111.3     83.0     107.9      39.3
Source: International Monetary Fund, 2007: estimates


14.      There has been a worsening of the current account deficit in 2008 compared to 2007. Much
of this has been driven by the continued slowdown in global demand coupled with high international
prices. An increase in the trade and services deficit between 2007 and 2008 has been the main driver of
the worsening current account deficit (including official transfers) which increased from 4.9 to 7.1
percent. The widening of the current account deficit would be compounded by a possible decrease in
donor grants should the global recession deepen.

Fiscal Performance

15.      The fiscal stance remained expansionary over 2008.            Total expenditure and net lending
increased from 24.9 to 27.1 percent of GDP between 2007 and 2008 (see Figure 1). This increase in
spending in 2008, in part, reflected a supplementary budget approved late in the year for additional
priority spending (in education, health, infrastructure and agriculture which accounted for roughly half of
spending). The result was a widening of the fiscal deficit (before grants) in 2008 to an estimated 13.8
percent of GDP from 11.1 percent in 2007. The rise in public expenditure has been financed by increases
in domestic revenues. Fiscal revenues as a percent of GDP rose from 13.6 percent of GDP in 2007 to
14.2 percent of GDP in 2008 due to higher growth and inflation, as well as taxation of growing imports.
The higher domestic tax revenue was largely attributable to revenue collection efforts. External grant
financing increased to 13 percent of GDP in 2008, from 9.8 percent in 2007.




                                                       4

                Figure 1: Government Revenue, Expenditure and Fiscal Balance (% of GDP)




                         Source: Rwandese Authorities Bank and IMF staff estimates.


Monetary and Financial Sector Policies and Performance

16.      The Rwanda Franc remained stable against the US Dollar in 2008. The nominal exchange
rate depreciated by 2.7 percent, year-on-year at the end of 2008, while the real effective exchange rate for
the first 8 months of 2008 appreciated by less then 0.5 percent on average compared to 2007. A new
method of determining the exchange rate was introduced in February 2008 and modified in June 2008 to
allow more exchange rate flexibility. The previous auction-based system to sell foreign currencies was
abolished in June 2007 and the NBR is now selling foreign exchange directly to commercial banks at the
day-to-day reference rate. A weekly adjustment is carried out against the US Dollar, based on the
performance of foreign exchange sales which is compared to a weekly target derived from the annual
projected amount of foreign exchange sales.

17.      The central bank is increasingly relying on the sale of foreign exchange to sterilize excess
liquidity and limit the sale of domestic instruments to meet the reserve money target agreed under
the PRGF.      Rising prices and the increased demand for money and currency in circulation also
contributed to a tight monetary situation. This led to a reduction in the excess reserves of banks. As a
result of the tighter monetary stance, broad money declined indicating a reduction in the monetary
overhang that persisted through early 2008 and that was caused by expansionary fiscal spending.
Government will continue to rely more on maintaining the flexibility of the exchange rate to contain the
growth in the money supply.

18.      Broad money supply (M2) growth slowed in 2008. M2 grew by 13.6 percent in 2008 compared
to 31 percent in 2007, reflecting the tighter monetary policy and reduction in the monetary overhang.
Budget support, development projects and private transfers contributed to the accumulation of foreign
reserves from US $552 million at the end of 2007 to US $599 million at the end of 2008 (representing a
growth rate of 9 percent). As a result, reserves remained at around 5 months of imports. Net credit to the
private sector, grew by 21 percent in 2007 and 20 percent in 2008. Credit to Government continued to
decrease in 2008 due to the high volume of external disbursements.

19.      To control inflation, the central bank uses various instruments, including setting the level of
reserve requirements, money market interventions, as well as an interest rate corridor and a policy
rate. Besides the overnight and 7-day instruments, a 4-week instrument has been reintroduced and
repurchase agreement operations ranging from 1 to 90 days have been established in 2008. The interest
rate structure of the money market will be adapted to the new instrument. Overall, the financial sector
indicators attest to the soundness of the sector and financial sector reforms are guided by the Financial



                                                         5

Sector Development Plan (FSDP), which was launched in 2007 to promote the growth and efficiency of
the financial sector. Recent progress includes the recapitalization of commercial banks, amendments to
the central bank act to enable the NBR to regulate insurance companies, the compliance of a number of
microfinance institutions with the new and higher capital requirements and the ongoing restructuring of
the payment system.

Debt Sustainability

20.     Debt as a share of GDP remains low (about 17 percent of GDP as of end-2007) following the
Multilateral Debt Relief Initiative in 2006. Domestic debt as a percentage of GDP fell from 12.1
percent in 2006 to 10.7 percent in 2007. However, despite stronger than expected export performance,
Rwanda's external debt situation was slightly less favorable. The NPV of external debt-to-exports ratio
rose to 72 at the end of 2007, up from 67 percent at end 2006. In terms of the composition by creditor,
about 72 percent of the public debt at end -2007 was with multilaterals and 12 percent with bi-laterals, the
remainder being domestic debt.

21.     The most recent DSA concludes that Rwanda is now at a moderate risk of debt distress due
to its narrow export base. With the exception of the net present value of exports to debt which breaches
the threshold of 150 under extreme stress tests, all debt indicators remain below their respective
thresholds. Exogenous shocks to exports or imprudent borrowing on non-concessional terms could cause
a rapid deterioration in the medium-term outlook. In response, the GoR has to date limited external debt
and kept to a minimum 50 percent grant element. In addition, a debt management strategy has been
prepared with limits for loans, government guarantees and contingent liabilities that will guide future
borrowing to prevent the reemergence of unsustainable debt.

22.     The infrastructure gap and large financing needs pose a significant challenge.
Considerations by the Government to partly finance large multiyear projects in priority sectors, necessary
to address the severe infrastructure constraints and boost agricultural productivity, on less concessional
terms, would result in a breach of the policy-dependent threshold of 150 percent by 2013. However, even
with this non-concessional financing, the NPV of external debt-to-GDP ratio and the NPV of debt-to-
revenue ratios will remain well below their thresholds, while debt service payments will continue to be
manageable at below 10 percent of exports.

                  B.     MEDIUM TERM PROSPECTS AND FINANCING REQUIREMENTS

23.     The GoR's medium term outlook is for real GDP growth to be maintained at 6 percent with
economic growth being driven by increased productivity in the agricultural and service sectors,
accompanied by strong public and private sector investment activity. This outlook is contingent on
favorable weather conditions in the next few years, continued implementation of policies to promote
commodity exports and successful implementation of the medium-term policy agenda as outlined in the
EDPRS on five fronts: (i) carrying out Government's planned investments in infrastructure; (ii)
improving agricultural yields, supported by actions in the new fertilizer strategy; (iii) sustaining progress
on the private sector development program; (iv) accelerating overall export growth and diversifying the
export base; and (v) taking actions aimed at enhancing the efficiency of investment as outlined in the new
Public Investment Policy. This would counter the apparent slowdown in growth, as the economy has
moved beyond the post-conflict recovery period, and raise growth from the average of 5.6 percent during
2003-2007 to about 6 percent over the period 2009-2011.

24.     The projected annual GDP growth of 6 percent would be sustained through increased
public and private sector investments to improve agriculture productivity and address
infrastructure constraints to growth. Reflecting the strong emphasis that GoR is placing on public



                                                  6

infrastructure investment, overall investment rates are projected to rise fairly steadily from about 21
percent of GDP in 2007, to about 23 percent of GDP by 2011. Public investment will increase from 8.6
percent in 2007 to close to 10 percent of GDP by 2011. With the private sector's engagement in the
social sectors and also in infrastructure expected to be strengthened, private investment would also trend
upward gradually to about 13 percent of GDP per year, in the medium-term.

25.      Strong import growth stemming from higher capital imports associated with the expanding
public investment program, is expected to outpace moderate expansion in exports, resulting in a
higher current account deficit. Export volumes led by receipts from traditional exports and tourism, are
forecasted to increase at a relatively slower rate as the GoR implements its export promotion strategy,
supported by the PRSG series. This is expected to widen the external current account deficit considerably
from about 5 percent of GDP (including grants) in 2007, to about 9.5 percent of GDP (including grants)
by 2011.

26.      Government capital spending would increase strongly over the medium term, in line with
the need for increased investment to accelerate and sustain growth, causing the overall fiscal balance to
remain in deficit. The deficit (including grants) would widen to about 3.0 percent of GDP by 2011, up
sharply from under 1.6 percent in 2007. Part of this increase would be due to higher investment, but the
projections also reflect the possibility of a continued high projected world price level of imports to
Rwanda.

27.      The share of priority spending will increase annually by about 2 percent of GDP depending
on the availability of sufficient resources. More resources will be dedicated to public infrastructure,
agriculture, education, health and water. Increased spending in the education sector will go towards
improving delivery of primary education and vocational training and skills development. In the heath
sector, focus will be on financing programs to improve primary heath care, financing of the mutuelle
scheme and purchase of drugs. Infrastructure spending will be geared towards addressing the issue of
limited and insufficient energy through construction of hydro power dams, generation of power from the
Lake Kivu Methane gas power plant, and rehabilitation of infrastructure. At the decentralized level,
transfers to districts are projected to increase as the Government implements its fiscal decentralization
policy, with increases in capitation grants in education and performance based financing in the health
sector, feeder roads financing in the transport sector and funds to cover district overhead costs.

28.      Consistent with the medium-term policy objective of maintaining macroeconomic stability,
the Central Bank is expected to contain inflationary pressures from any fiscal expansion and
scaled-up external assistance. Average inflation is expected to decline from around 15 percent in 2008,
due to rising food, transport and energy prices, to single digits by 2009. The reduction in inflation reflects
the price pass through from declining international food prices and domestic policy. Projections are that
with strong implementation of monetary policy, inflation could decline to single digits over 2009-12.

29.      The above medium-term outlook assumes that Rwanda continues to be able to cushion itself
from the adverse impacts of the global slow down. The impact of the global slow down on Rwanda's
economic growth rates, over the medium term, will depend on how strongly the drivers of growth ­i.e.
agriculture and services-- are impacted. Some of the large scale investments that are expected to be
funded from external borrowing and investment in the energy and agriculture sectors will be critical for
growth. These could be adversely impacted as the global economic slow down persists and external
resources become scarce. All of this could potentially lead to stronger adverse growth effects in the
medium to longer term.

30.      Continuation of the global economic slowdown would result in significant downside risks to
the balance of payments, remittances, FDI, and external finance. The greater risk to the balance of



                                                    7

payments would result from a reduction in grants should budget support donors have to substantially
curtail their commitments. External finance as a share of GDP amounts to 13 percent (or close to 50
percent of the budget). In contrast remittances and FDI, although they have increased significantly in
recent years, are still estimated, in total, to be around 5 percent of GDP. Therefore, the greater immediate
risk to the Government program would arise from a sudden and significant reduction in grants.

                       Box 1: Likely Impact of the Global Economic Crisis in Rwanda, 2008-2010

At present, the global economic slowdown has had a limited effect on Rwanda's economy due to its relatively closed
nature. However, a continued global slowdown would negatively effect GDP growth through the impact on grants, foreign
investment, remittances and the financial sector. There would need to be a downward revision on spending as revenue declines,
particularly if foreign aid becomes scarce. Export receipts would also be negatively affected leading to a widening of the current
account deficit. Also, health and education outcomes are particularly susceptible to household economic conditions. Financing
of services could be adversely affected due to lower revenues, reduced household ability to pay user fees, and any potential
reductions in grants.

A continued global slowdown would lead to projected growth of around 6 percent (compared to 8.5 percent for 2008),
over the medium term. The lower growth trend would arise from lower tourism receipts, reduction in remittances and a
slowdown in the construction sector. Over the medium term, growth would be driven by increased productivity in agriculture in
line with implementation of the Crop Intensification Program. The expected impact of the crisis over the medium-term is
expected to be relatively limited due both to the low level of integration with the global economy and the relatively high
dependence on subsistence agriculture.

Despite the strong increase in export receipts of coffee, tea, minerals and tourism, the trade deficit is expected to widen in
2009 due to the higher growth in import payments. An appreciation of the Rwandan franc would exacerbate the situation.
Over the medium term, with continued strong growth in volume and production, exports are projected to grow at 10 percent per
annum, which will be outpaced by imports growth of 20 percent per annum. As a result, the current account deficit is projected
to increase from US $303.5 million (or 7.1 percent of GDP) in 2008 to US $400.7 million (or 8.2 percent of GDP) in 2009
(including official transfers). To date, no large reductions in foreign direct investment (FDI), grants and borrowing are
expected as most planned investments have already been reconfirmed by donors. Although there are no visible pressures on
the balance of payment yet, a continued global recession would eventually lead to lower grants. As a precaution, given last
year's high level of inflation, GoR will reduce spending if necessary.

The fiscal program in 2008 remained broadly on track despite increased expenditures for the purchase of seed, fertilizer,
and food storage (largely financed by grants from IDA and AfDB, and the road maintenance fund). Revenues outperformed
their targets reflecting an increase in collections from income and consumption taxes, high inflation and GDP growth. Although
it is too early to get a good assessment of the overall and concrete impacts of the global financial crisis, the authorities are taking
proactive measures to mitigate any possible negative impacts. In its mini-budget for January to June 2009, fiscal policy is aiming
at: i) limiting contingent spending; and ii) saving higher-than-programmed revenues for future use. The budget deficit is
expected to remain on track for 2009 due partly to these measures.

In terms of the financial sector, all 8 commercial banks have been in compliance with the minimum capital requirements
of FRw 5 billion (approx. $9.2 million); foreign exchange exposure ratios reported have been within the prudential BNR
benchmarks; and the quality of the credit portfolio has improved. As of end June 2008, gross non-performing loans (NPLs)
reached FRw 32.2 billion against FRw 40.1 billion in December 2007 and the average ratio of NPLs to total loans declined to 12
percent from 18.5 percent in 2007. Although to date there is yet no impact of the crisis on the level of capitalization of banks and
NPLs, slower growth could result in rising credit risks increasing the vulnerability of the banking sector.

To manage the pressure of high resource inflows on inflation, the Central Bank has instituted measures to increase the
flexibility of the exchange rate enabling more effective sterilization of liquidity (which is the Central Bank's primary
instrument for monetary policy). In the last six months, the real exchange rate appreciated by 15 percent following the rise in the
US dollar--to which the Rwandan franc is closely tied--against other currencies. It has been exacerbated by the high rate of
domestic inflation (estimated at 22 percent in December 2008). The result has been a rising demand for foreign exchange and
imports. This acceleration in imports relative to exports is a concern for the authorities even as world commodity prices continue
to fall. Despite higher sales of foreign currency by the authorities, foreign exchange reserves exceeded programmed levels due to
higher than expected external budget support disbursements. As a result, the actual level of international reserves was $580.7
million at end September 2008, and is estimated to have increased to $599 million by end-2008.


Adequacy of the Macro-Economic Policy Framework

31.        Overall, the medium term macro-economic framework is assessed to be sound and adequate
to support the Government's program. As noted by the recently completed fifth review of the IMF's



                                                               8

PRGF, the medium-term outlook, including inflation, economic growth and financing remains favorable,
even though risks of contagion from the deteriorating external environment have increased. GoR will
continue to exercise prudence in implementation of macro-economic policy with a focus on ensuring
coordinated fiscal and monetary policies. It will also continue with structural reforms that will help raise
investment rates, expand the private sector, deepen the financial sector, and diversify the production and
export base. In particular, there is an emphasis on private sector led growth through the development of a
Public Investment Program, implementation of the Financial Sector Development Plan and the Rural
Development Program. Investments are planned to improve agriculture productivity, reduce soil erosion
and improve irrigation. There is also evidence that the investments in the energy sector aimed at reducing
the dependence on thermal power is paying off with the progress made in power generation in the Lake
Kivu electricity project. This along with investments in the Nyaborongo hydro-power project will help
reduce the cost of energy to firms and households. GoR is also now in the process of developing a
strategic plan for post-basic education to address the issue of skills development. These measures should
help to expand productivity and establish the foundation for long-term sustainable growth.

32.     In terms of external financing, GoR will continue to rely mainly on grants and highly
concessional borrowing to safeguard debt sustainability. Borrowing decisions will be guided by the
new debt management strategy and a medium-term public expenditure management framework.
Infrastructure projects that are needed to alleviate bottlenecks to private sector growth will be carefully
evaluated on a case-by-case basis in terms of their cost-effectiveness and impact on the public debt. In
addition, the ongoing and planned reforms in public financial management that are outlined in the
Government's Public Financial Management Strategy and Action Plan will help ensure that public
resources are allocated efficiently. Finally, GoR will continue its efforts to expand the local tax base and
improve tax administration, with the aim of increasing revenue collection and reducing the dependence on
aid.

                                         Table 3: Financing Plan 2008-11 (US$ millions)

External Financial Requirements

33.     Strong import growth stemming from higher capital imports associated with an expanding
public investment program, is expected to outpace moderate expansion in exports, led by receipts



                                                                   9

from traditional exports (particularly coffee), and tourism. This will keep the current account in deficit
and rising over the medium term. Accordingly, external financing requirements would grow to about
$2.66 billion over 2009-2011. With about $2.62 billion in identified financing (largely from grants,
concessional loans, and private capital inflows, including foreign direct investment), the program is fully
financed during PRSG-5. For the PRSG-6 period, the projection is that the program will continue to be
fully financed. Should there be an unforeseen shortfall of grants (compared to projections), Government
will revise the spending plan as needed.


                                  III. GOVERNMENT'S PROGRAM


34.      The Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EDPRS), the Government's
second-generation PRSP that lays out a development plan for 2008-2012, was launched in
September 2007. It outlines the strategies and actions to stimulate rapid growth and lead to the reduction
of poverty in line with the Government's national vision document (Vision 2020) and the MDGs, under
three flagships:     (i) Sustainable Growth for Jobs and Exports; (ii) Vision 2020 Umurenge; and
(iii)Governance.

35.      The EDPRS builds upon and aims to consolidate gains achieved under the PRSP-1 reform
program. The broad reform program, (summarized in Annex 6), is focused on laying the overarching
institutional/ legal/regulatory framework, for the key areas of focus of the PRSP. Several key pieces of
legislation were enacted under PRSP-1, including the updated Organic Budget Law, the Organic
Education Law, the Land Law, and the Procurement Law, thereby establishing the legal and regulatory
framework for the implementation of the EDPRS in these critical areas. In addition, sector strategy
development was advanced in the Agriculture, Health and Education sectors with the adoption of the
Strategic Plan for Agricultural Transformation (PSTA), the Health Sector Strategic Plan (2005-2009), and
the Education Sector Strategic Plan (ESSP 2005-2008). In the agriculture sector, several new agencies
were created to support the institutional reforms needed to strengthen the research and extension system,
as well as improve inspection and quality. These agencies include the Rwanda Agricultural Development
Authority which is charged with development of appropriate technologies and the dissemination of these
through advisory, outreach and extension services to stakeholders in the agriculture sector with the aim of
modernizing the sector. In the livestock sector, research and extension is under the purview of the
Rwanda Animal Resources Development Authority.              In addition, the former Rwanda Investment
Promotion Agency was restructured into the Rwanda Investment and Export Promotion Agency to
strengthen its role in export promotion and trade facilitation. The office of tourism promotion (ORTPN)
was restructured to better support development of the sector. In the case of public financial management
and procurement, the School of Finance and Banking was created to support development of the
accounting and finance professionals which has been direly lacking. Furthermore, the National Tender
Board was created with the aim of improving transparency in procurement; the Office of the Accountant
General was created, and that of the Auditor General was restructured to align with the updated Organic
Budget Law.

Progress in implementation under Flagship 1: Growth for Jobs and Exports

36.      Recent reforms under this flagship have focused on deepening the financial sector,
improving the quality of infrastructure and related services, fostering increased trade and regional
integration, and laying the foundation for a more skilled labor force. Progress in the implementation
of the Financial Sector Development Plan (FSDP), adopted in 2007, is evident from recent laws that have
been passed to improve regulation of insurance companies and combat money laundering (passed
respectively in July and October of 2008). Reforms have also focused on consolidating the banking and
insurance supervision, in line with international standards; and development of a payment systems bill to



                                                   10

establish a clear framework for oversight for the central bank and settlements. In addition, the Union des
Banques Populaire (UBPR), previously a large microfinance network obtained a commercial banking
license in mid-February 2008 and entered into a strategic partnership with a banking group from the
Netherlands which now owns 35 percent of the shares in UBPR. Micro-finance institutions also complied
with higher minimum capital requirements in 2008.          Finally, an over-the counter debt market was
launched in January 2008, listing four bonds, and the Capital Market Advisory Council was established.
Furthermore, the Executive Secretariat of the Council is operational and the first bonds have been issued.


37.      Aside from reforms to strengthen the financial sector, Rwanda is engaged in a number of
regional initiatives in the energy and transport sectors to improve road transport and connectivity
of trade routes. Some of these initiatives are financed by the World Bank. These include investments to
strengthen transport and communication links to markets in neighboring countries that are being financed
through the East Africa Trade and Transport Facilitation Project, the Regional Trade Facilitation Project,
and the Regional Communications Infrastructure Project which are discussed further in section IV below.
Rwanda is also engaged in regional initiatives to develop greater ICT connectivity in the region.


38.      Within the country, several laws have been passed in the power sector with the aim of
establishing the institutional, legal and regulatory framework to promote increased private sector
involvement in the electricity and transport sectors ­namely, through public private partnerships. Two
separate laws were enacted to separate the electricity and water utilities with the aim of improving cost
recovery and efficient service provision. Also, the National Energy Development Agency was created to
promote and facilitate implementation of energy policy and strategy, supporting pilot activities and
capacity building, with a focus on household energy, biomass, small scale renewable energy, and off-grid
developmental activities, as well as related oversight, monitoring and reporting. Creation of NEDA will
over time leave MININFRA to focus on policy setting as its main function. In the transport sector, a
Transport Policy and Road Maintenance Strategy were completed and adopted by Cabinet defining
priorities and approaches to strengthen institutions for efficient operation of the sector, and involvement
of the private sector and local communities.    In the water sector, Government will continue to promote
private-public partnerships and private participation in the operation of piped, rural water supply systems.
The Water Ministry is working on a program to encourage investment in the water and sanitation sub-
sector; a number of donors are in the process of mobilizing funds to scale up their efforts in this area. The
creation of a Water Commission to be responsible for service delivery is currently under legislative
review and could be established some time next year.

39.      In terms of skills development, having achieved significant growth in enrollment, the focus
is now turned to improving quality of nine year basic education, raising completion rates and
strengthening post-basic education. A comprehensive strategy for post-basic education, including the
formulation of a technical and vocational education and training (TVET) policy and a higher education
policy have been adopted by Cabinet. However, the sector is missing two key policy components to fully
realize its goals of producing a skilled and flexible labor force ready to respond to the challenges of a
global economy. The two policy components are a secondary education policy; and an overall strategy
for integrating all aspects of post-basic education. This will require a change from a secondary school
system that caters to very few academically inclined students for limited slots in universities to a mass
system which prepares all young people for a lifetime of learning and changing economic opportunities.
Such a transformation of the education system requires changes in content, structure, and organization
which will need to be explicitly addressed in Rwanda's education policy framework.


40.      Finally, Government has begun implementation of the STI Policy drawing on the results of
the recently completed needs assessment. The STI Policy responds to the challenges and potential
impediments identified in the Vision 2020 and proposes detailed actions to address each of these


                                                   11

impediments. These can be divided into four categories: (i) Governance of STI; (ii) Human capacity to
implement STI programs; (iii) Knowledge generation and technology transfer to rural villages and local
businesses; and (iv) STI infrastructure and support systems. The policy puts emphasis on promotion of
knowledge acquisition, creation, transfer, and a culture of innovation.

Progress in implementation under Flagship 2: Vision 2020 Umurenge


41.     Flagship two (Vision 2020 Umurenge or VUP) focuses on ensuring shared growth and on the
creation of opportunities for the poorest Rwandans. It has four components (public works, credit
packages, and direct income support) that involve four complementary elements: (i) agricultural
productivity improvement for households with land; (ii) publicly funded, socially productive, labor-
intensive employment for landless Rwandans without job opportunities; (iii) social assistance for landless
people incapable of work; and (iv) improved access to credit for input purchases or micro-enterprise
development by members of households assisted through elements (i)­(iii).

42.     The VUP is currently in the pilot phase, and is targeted to the rural areas of the poorest
villages in each of the 30 districts. Pilots have started in 25 of the 30 districts. Government is also in
the process of elaborating the institutional framework for coordination and implementation of the VUP
which the Bank will support through a three year sector budget support operation to be focused on public
works, micro-finance schemes and development of community health services.             In that regard, the
Ministry of Health (MINISANTE) has implemented measures to strengthen the link between community
health services and family planning with the aim of reducing population growth.              In particular,
MINISANTE has doubled the budget for family planning services in the coming year and transferred
resources from certain HIV projects to next year's budget for family planning.             There are also
complementary off-budget targeted resources, such as programs supported by USAID.


43.     A number of substantial reforms have also been instituted in the health sector to support
increased coordination. The initiation of a SWAp process has facilitated an increased commitment to
on-budget financing that includes budget support and more ring-fenced mechanisms. This has led to
increased public financing of health services from US$26 per capita in 2006 to US$33 in 2008. With
regard to the specific indicators monitored in the health sector, 60 percent of children under five used
insecticide-treated bed nets in 2007. In 2008, 52 percent of births were attended by skilled personnel; and
75 percent of the population was covered by community-based (mutuelle) health insurance.


Progress in implementation under Flagship 3: Governance


44.     Flagship three (Governance) seeks to strengthen political and economic governance,
building institutions and capacity of the state. Emphasis is given to maintaining peace and security,
promoting peace and reconciliation amongst Rwandans, reforming the justice system to uphold human
rights and the rule of law, and empowering citizens to participate in their own social, political and
economic development. A wide range of reforms are envisaged to strengthen public sector institutions
and capacity including further decentralization, enhancing accountability at all levels of government,
strengthening public financial management and increasing the predictability and transparency of policy-
making. The other elements of the flagship include improvements in the "soft infrastructure" needed to
strengthen commercial justice systems, business and land registration reforms, and regulatory frameworks
to promote good corporate governance.

45.     Recent reforms have been centered on strengthening the framework for public financial
management.       In December 2007, Parliament passed the Accountants Bill which now requires all



                                                  12

financial institutions and large and public companies to comply with International Accounting Standards
(IAS) and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). District budget reports are now published
on the Government's website. Guidelines to budget agencies for preparation of the MTEF have been
completed and were produced on the MINECOFIN website in June 2008. Following consultations with
development partners, the PFM reform strategy and action plan for 2008-2012 was published in
September.      Government is in the process of elaborating a framework for strategic guidance,
implementation, monitoring, and financing of the PFM reform strategy. This will facilitate coordination
in implementation of the strategy. In line with identified needs, capacity building and training in PFM is
ongoing.


46.      The legal text to establish the Rwanda Public Procurement Authority (RPPA) which is in
line with international best practice was adopted and gazetted and the board of directors appointed
in March 2008. The text includes all functions belonging to a modern procurement regulatory and
oversight body. In addition, procurement audits were completed in 66 procuring entities (80 audits in
total were scheduled). Also, independent review panels have been established and made operational at
the national and district levels (according to the law, 5 members are from the private sector and civil
society organizations). Bidders on public procurement contracts have recourse to independent appeal.
Finally, the NTB website now publishes a list of debarred firms.


47.      There has also been progress in reforms to strengthen the civil service. MIFOTRA has
completed the functional audit of 6 ministries (MIFOTRA, MINECOFIN, MINISANTE, MINEDUC,
MINITERE, and MININFRA) - the results of the review will be used to develop an action plan for each
ministry to address the issues raised pertaining to weaknesses in the structure, staffing and procedures. A
monitoring framework for the EDPRS has also been developed along with a CPAF around which all
budget support donors have agreed to focus and align their fiduciary requirements.


Overall Implementation, Monitoring and Harmonization Arrangements


48.      Significant progress has been made in the process of harmonization, alignment and mutual
accountability of donors and Government. A Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF)
to provide a framework for monitoring the EDPRS was concluded, along with a framework for
monitoring the progress of donors toward the Paris 21 initiative. The CPAF was drawn from fully
developed EDPRS sector policy matrices outlining the medium term policy actions and outcomes based
on agreed sector priorities. Some of these matrices are drawn from well developed or documented sector
strategies and will form the basis for undertaking sector reviews (undertaken through the SWGs), that will
in turn inform the overall Joint Budget Support Review (involving the joint review of progress in key
areas of the CPAF on an annual basis against planned and actual expenditures).                   Eight new
Implementation Working Groups (IWGs) reflecting the priority thematic areas of the EDPRS serve as the
forum to coordinate across sectors, and between government and development partners, to discuss policy
issues and monitoring of the EDPRS. Each IWG comprises stakeholders from related sector working
groups. In addition, a Partnership Agreement laying out procedures and modalities for a multi-donor
approach to budgetary support was signed in October 2008, between the Government and the key budget
support donors. Also, Sector-Wide Approaches have been adopted in the energy, agriculture and health
sectors as a means of having a coordinated framework and sustained financing for reforms in these areas.
This has also involved the development of a medium term expenditure framework linked to EDPRS
priorities for each sector. However, to date, only the agriculture sector has a comprehensive strategy
document.




                                                   13

                 IV. BANK SUPPORT TO THE GOVERNMENT PROGRAM

                             A. LINK TO THE CAS AND OTHER BANK OPERATION

49.     The Banks support to the implementation of the EDPRS is detailed in the FY09-12 CAS
that was discussed by the Board on September 26, 2008. The CAS seeks stronger impact through
greater selectivity and is organized around two strategic themes: the first concentrates on activities that
will promote economic transformation and remove bottlenecks to growth; the second pillar brings
together activities geared toward reducing social vulnerability. In addition, it further sets as its objectives
a strong collaboration with Government, as well as a stronger focus on results and outcomes and
harmonization among development partners. With the PRSG program seen as the overall umbrella
for Bank support and policy dialogue, these themes will be largely supported through the PRSG
series and complemented by select investment lending.

50.     The proposed operation, in alignment with the EDPRS and the CAS themes, continues to
focus on three main areas: (i) promoting sustainable growth and private sector development supported
by science, technology and innovation; (ii) increasing capacity to implement the Governments
decentralization program and budget reforms, with particular attention to strengthening district reporting;
and (iii) continuing to support improvements in service delivery with a focus on economic and
infrastructure services and on increasing the availability of skilled labor.         All of these areas are
interrelated and mutually reinforcing. The PRSG program is designed and implemented to take advantage
of these synergies.

51.     The PRSG program builds on and complements a solid base of a well-performing IDA
portfolio. There are currently 11 active projects in Rwanda and several sectoral investment projects are
planned to complement the support of the PRSG series in the key focal areas of infrastructure
development and capacity building including the Electricity Access Roll-Out project, Transport Sector
Development Project and the Land Harvesting Water Management and Hillside Irrigation project. In
addition, Rwanda is participating in three regional infrastructure projects (see Annex 8).

52.     The regional projects are designed to strengthen Rwanda's links to regional markets
through improved trade facilitation and a reduction in the cost of doing business regionally. The
HIV/AIDS Great Lakes Initiative contributes to the reduction of HIV infections and is focused on the
prevention, care, and treatment of HIV/AIDS for mobile, and vulnerable groups such as refugees,
transport sector workers, and highly affected/infected populations within the region. The East Africa
Trade and Transport Facilitation Project supports specific measures targeted at the EAC to strengthen
implementation of the customs union and related market; improve efficiency of the supply chains in and
out of the region and along the main trade routes; support the development of an integrated system and
common database linking customs departments in the member states and Rwanda to the EAC Customs
directory in Arusha.    The Regional Trade Facilitation Project's is targeted at the COMESA and
addresses the concerns of risks related to a lack of policy continuity and consistency by providing
insurance against the risk of a reversal in the government's policies which negatively affects business.
The insurance facility also covers losses resulting from the occurrence of war and civil disturbance, thus
addressing the second component of country risk that impedes increased private sector capital flows to the
region.   The Regional Communications Infrastructure Project aims to reduce the cost of doing
business in Rwanda and contribute to the government's ability to implement e-Government. It will
support investments and technical assistance to lower prices for international capacity and extend the
geographic reach of broadband networks

53.     Finally there will be a parallel programmatic DPO series to support the GoRs
implementation of social protection and community health strategies.                   This operation will



                                                  14

complement the PRSG focus on growth with a focus on poverty reduction, particularly in rural areas. The
PRSG series will therefore be more focused on economic and infrastructure related constraints to growth,
on measures to improve the supply of skilled labor, and on deepening reforms in service delivery. In
addition, the PRSG will support the implementation of recommendations arising from the Science
Technology and Innovation (STI) report that are key to the transformation of the economy.

                           B. COORDINATION WITH THE IMF AND OTHER DONORS

54.      Coordination with the IMF: The proposed PRSG has been prepared in parallel with the PRGF
review and coincides with the Article IV review that took place in October 2008. The aim is to ensure
coordination and consistency in the macroeconomic and structural policy programs of the PRSG and
IMF's Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF). The PRSG's focus on structural and institutional
reforms, to improve the quality of spending and program implementation and to support growth,
complements the IMF's areas of focus as it leads the macro dialogue.

55.      Coordination with Other Donors: Donors are collaborating to support Rwanda in implementing
the EDPRS, by providing financial and technical support in a coordinated way. Key coordination
mechanisms including the Development Partners Coordination Group (DPCG), the Budget Support
Harmonization Group (BSHG), and Sector (i.e. SWGs) and cross sector Clusters or Implementation
Working Groups have been formed by Government. These groups have been involved in preparatory
consultations and joint review of the implementation of Rwanda's Poverty Reduction Strategy through
the biannual joint budget support donor missions that were initiated in 2004.

56.      The PRSG continues to seek synergies with other donor programs and projects through
continued support to the use and development of sector-wide approaches, currently being
undertaken in the context of Sector Working Groups (SWGs). In addition, as of the 2009 budget
year, all budget support donors, including the Bank through PRSG 5, are now fully aligned to the CPAF.
The framework for alignment is outlined in the Partnership Agreement, including procedures and
modalities for a multi-donor approach to budgetary support. This was signed by the Government and the
key budget support donors in October 2008. The measures supported by this operation draw on the new
framework and have been adapted from triggers outlined in PRSG-4 in order to fully integrate this
operation with the CPAF.

                                   C.    ANALYTICAL UNDERPINNINGS

57.      PRSG-5 builds on analytical work carried out over the last few years, as well as ongoing
analytical work on public expenditure management to support Pillar 1 (Jobs for Growth and
Exports), and Pillar 3 (Governance) of the EDPRS. Analytical work completed during the last year
includes the FY07 Country Economic Memorandum, the FY07 Agriculture Policy Note, and the FY07
Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability Assessment. The Multi-year TA public expenditure
review (PER) currently underway will play a major role in implementation of PRSG activities by
informing the prioritization of measures to improve the quality of spending in the PRSG series. It is also
providing technical assistance to the Government for the institutionalization of the PER process while the
Debt Sustainability Analysis (DSA) update, recently completed in close collaboration with the IMF and in
consultation with the Government aims to ensure macroeconomic stability. The program also builds on
analytical work carried out by the Government including the FY06 Poverty Report and the Financial
Sector Development Plan. This section highlights three areas of analytic work that support the policy
dialogue under the PRSG: (i) drivers of growth and poverty reduction, (ii) sectoral work, and (iii)
governance or fiduciary issues. Box 2 outlines the key constraints to growth which this PRSG series aims
to address based on the results of the above listed analytical works.




                                                   15

58.     Drivers of growth and poverty reduction--the importance of infrastructure and agriculture.
The Country Economic Memorandum (FY07) entitled Rwanda: Towards Sustained Growth and
Competitiveness identifies the poor condition of infrastructure, low base of skilled labor and the low use
of modern inputs, improved seeds in agriculture, as the major constraints to growth and comes to the
following conclusions and strategic priorities. In the short to medium term, the focus should be on
improving productivity in the agricultural sector.       In the medium to long term, increased capital
investment to reduce the costs of energy, water and transport and to increase the supply of skilled labor
are needed.    The recently completed Investment Climate Assessment (FY08) also highlights the
importance of attention to the infrastructure constraints, as well as the need to deepen the financial sector.
In particular, the FIAS study of informal enterprises highlights the need to improve financial
intermediation and build capacity of micro-enterprises to access micro-finance. The study identifies the
low level capacity in business development skills and lack of information on the kinds of credit
instruments that are available and how to access these. Salient findings include the following: (i) 52
percent of Rwandans do not use either formal or informal financial products; (ii) 77 percent of those who
use financial products use informal products; (iii) bank usage is dominated by the BPR; (iv) excluding
BPR, only 1 percent of the adult population uses formal bank products.

59.     The recently completed Investment Climate Assessment (ICA) for Rwanda highlights the
continued constraint posed by the poor state of infrastructure to economic growth and regional
competitiveness. Over 70 percent of firms in the manufacturing sector reported electricity to be a major
constraint. Almost 40 percent of firms in Rwanda said that transportation was a serious obstacle, higher
than all comparators for the EAC, except Kenya, where 53 percent of firms ranked transport as a serious
obstacle. Finally, subjective ratings by transport operators in Rwanda were significantly lower than that
of operators in the rest of the other EAC countries. Transport and energy (see Figure 4) costs as a share
of sales continues to be higher in Rwanda compared to EAC comparator countries.

60.     The poverty update also highlights the importance of infrastructure to Rwanda's
competitiveness and economic growth. The findings of this poverty analysis appear to validate the
policy directions proposed in the EDPRS, and supported by the PRSGs, namely the importance of: (i)
prudent management of public finances to preserve the funding for growth enhancing and poverty
reducing sectors; (ii) extending infrastructure services in rural areas, particularly road access to markets
and electrical supply, to mitigate poverty among rural households; and (iii) sustaining increases in
agricultural productivity for maintaining the long term trends in broad based growth and poverty
reduction.

61.     Sectoral Work. Analytic work at the sector level forms an integral part of sector development
programs and thematic reform programs. Priority issues for analytic work are typically discussed during
annual sector reviews. In the education sector, the Joint Reviews of the Education Sector (JRES) have
increasingly focused on the quality of education in Rwanda. Challenges raised include inability to attract
and retain skilled teachers due to low salary levels, particularly for primary teachers, slow progress in
universal completion of quality primary education, (currently at 51.7 percent), transition to upper
secondary, monitoring and evaluation of school and district level performance. The updated country
status report will reflect recent developments in decentralization and resulting implications for the sector.
An impact evaluation of performance-based contracting which will be used to strengthen the design of the
performance based system is currently underway. Work is ongoing to underpin the development of a
strategy for vocational and technical education and skills development.

62.     The Science, Technology and Innovation Needs Assessment for Rwanda (financed from the
Norwegian Post-Primary Education Trust Fund), outlines several concrete recommendations to




                                                   16

improve Rwanda's STI capacity.2 Six priority STI capacity building areas identified by the joint
Government/Bank team that prepared the report include: food-processing, value-added exports,
development and diffusion of appropriate technologies, delivery of clean drinking water, geo-sciences and
geothermal energy, and client-focused agricultural research and outreach. Recommendations from the
report include, for example, a stronger focus of teaching and research efforts on training Rwandans to use
knowledge to develop, produce, and deploy high performance, low-cost technologies. Examples of these
technologies include: more efficient wood burning stoves; manual irrigation pumps; food-processing and
storage equipment; more efficient, low-cost construction materials and methods; and non-electrical
refrigeration and food-cooling equipment.

63.      The report on water legislation and institutions led to the drafting and approval of the water law
by Parliament, the implementation of which is being supported under this PRSG series. The report on
water data management stresses the need for further capacity building in monitoring activities through the
use of a network, to improve coordination for the development of an integrated water resources
development and management program.


                           Box 2: Main Constraints to Economic Growth and Exports in Rwanda

 The 2007 Country Economic Memorandum (CEM) identifies three major areas of constraints to growth in Rwanda: This
 includes the poor water management, low use of modern inputs such as fertilizers and improved seeds and lack of
 extension services in agriculture; the poor condition of infrastructure ­ particularly electricity, transport, and water ­ that
 has limited the development of the manufacturing and service sectors; and the low base of skilled labor, particularly
 technical and managerial skills. In addition to the results of the CEM, the Diagnostic Trade Integrated Study and the
 recently completed Investment Climate Assessment identified infrastructure costs as a major factor lowering the returns to
 trade and exports. These documents note that improving productivity and supply is critical to improving exports.

 The table below shows, substantial gains in productivity can be realized through appropriate use of improved inputs in
 agriculture. Furthermore, the dependence on rain-fed agriculture, environmental degradation leading to severe soil erosion,
 lack of investment on irrigation and poor water management, have been the key factors undermining agricultural productivity
 and growth. On infrastructure, the 2005 Rwanda Industry and Manufacturing Survey (RIMS) showed that 81 percent of firms
 ranked power shortage as the highest constraint to their business and 41 percent of firms cited transport costs as a constraint.
 In addition, capacity utilization of manufacturing firms was estimated to be around 60 percent and closely tied to power
 shortage. The RIMS also showed that 40 percent of firms consider the availability of skilled labor a major constraint to their
 operations. The low scarcity of technical skills hinders development across manufacturing, service and agricultural sectors as
 well as small-scale enterprises and the public sector. It also limits innovation.
                             Yield Response to Fertilizer usage and Improved Seeds in Rwanda,
                                                   Selected Crops (In Tons/Ha)


                                                 Potential Yield                    Average Yield

                           Irish Potato                       25-20                              8.6
                           Rice                                   7.0                            3.7
                           Tea                                    3.5                            1.3
                           Coffee                                 2.4                            1.6
                           Beans (dwarf)                          1.5                            0.8
                           Climbing Beans                         3-4                            0.8
                           Maize                               3.5-6                             0.8
                           Banana                             25-35                            5-10


 Bureaucratic and administrative costs of doing business are also high in Rwanda. The Rwanda Investment and Export
 Promotion Agency (RIEPA) is taking the lead in implementing the Government's Doing Business action plan following the
 deliberations in the Doing Business (DB) workshop of April 2007. Actions have been focused on areas where immediate
 improvements can be made, particularly on trade facilitation and customs, registering property and trading across boundaries.
 This effort is being supported with technical assistance from the Bank's CEDP project, in close collaboration with IFC and
 FIAS.

 Source: Rwanda CEM (2007) and Rwanda ICA (2008).

Problems. Available at www.worldbank.org/sti.
