                                                     18

64.     Detailed analysis of the agriculture sector is contained in the Agricultural Policy Note (FY07)
which identified the underlying causes of low profitability of agriculture as among others, low farm-level
productivity, limited availability and high costs of agricultural inputs and a weak human capital base.
Recommendations therefore include stimulating productivity growth in food staples, scaling up
sustainable development of land and water resources, overhauling national agricultural research and
extension systems and promoting agricultural export growth and diversification. The Financial Sector
Development Plan (FSDP) identified the need to develop the microfinance sector as critical to monetizing
and deepening the financial sector. The report highlights the importance of developing the payment
system if Rwanda is to reduce its predominance of cash transactions in the system, particularly given the
country's vision of developing the tourism sector and a service based economy. The DTIS highlights the
importance of reducing the cost of infrastructure services to stimulating export growth and trade. Finally,
the CEM highlights the problem posed by the high level of maintenance costs with low cost recovery that
affects upkeep of the infrastructure network and its efficiency. This also has an impact on investments.
In the road sector, maintenance is constrained by the lack of road maintenance funds. In the electricity
sector, poor maintenance has contributed to high transmission losses and frequent outages.

65.     Governance and Fiduciary Work. Ongoing and existing analytical work on fiduciary
arrangements set out action plans for improvements in public financial management and public
procurement, providing important insights for the preparation of this operation. These works include the
FY07 PEFA, which highlights the importance of continuing to support capacity in pubic financial
accounting and reporting particularly at decentralized levels, MTEF development, and procurement. The
recently completed Public Financial Management (PFM) Action Plan outlines a costed plan for reforms to
strengthen PFM capacity. These will be key areas of support under the PRSG series. Another update of
the debt sustainability analysis (DSA) has been recently completed in close collaboration with the IMF
and in consultation with the Government to ensure that the Government's expenditure program does not
jeopardize macro economic stability.

66.     Non-lending activities will continue to play a major role in the implementation of PRSG
activities, and will focus on capacity building. As mentioned previously, a technical assistance in
support of improving public expenditure management is currently underway. In addition, a Multi-year
Agriculture Policy technical assistance is ongoing to complement financial operations and investment
projects in the sector.

67.     Aside from ongoing and completed analytical works, several studies are planned to support
the PRSG agenda including: (i) additional science and technology needs assessments and action plans to
identify STI capacity building programs to support the infrastructure and financial sectors; (ii) a labor
study focused on skills development and employment generation, to improve understanding of the
employment and poverty effects of past growth; and (iii) an Education Policy Analysis.

                           D.     LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREVIOUS PRSGS

68.     The Implementation Completion Report of PRSG 1 to 3, along with experience from PRSG-
4 reinforced the importance of capacity in terms of lessons that will be reflected in the PRSG-5 and
PRSG-6. First, strong Government commitment backed with Bank support to reinforce capacity to
implement has led to substantial achievements of targeted outcomes and reforms.            This has been
particularly evident in the education, health, water and agriculture sectors that have received support in
the development of sector strategies and MTEFs. Bank support has also greatly facilitated the move to
SWAps in the education, health, agriculture and energy sectors.         Similar momentum is also being
generated in the transport sector. Therefore, support to developing sector strategies, MTEFs and SWAps
continues to be a key area of assistance under PRSG-5 and PRSG-6.




                                                  19

69.      Second, there has been a need for strong capacity support in the area of fiscal
decentralization and civil service reform. Government successfully implemented an ambitious and
challenging civil service and decentralization reform program, including large retrenchments. However,
thinly spread out staff coupled with low retention and incentives continues to be an issue. The World
Bank through the second PRSG series (and in close collaboration with other key donors supporting
reforms in these areas ­i.e. DFID, Netherlands, German Corporation) will continue support to put in place
incentives for capacity strengthening and retention of civil service staff. Measures to be included under
the PRSG-5 support these areas of the Government's reform program.

70.      Third, the PRSG series has enabled (even in the case where there are already existing
complementary sector projects) elevation of the policy dialogue in key sectors such as energy and
water. This has enabled more in depth discussion and follow-up of policy issues compared to the
situation where sectors are engaged only through project support. An example in the water sector pertains
to support to local private operator schemes and in energy an example is that of the issue of extra energy
generation capacity and related policy reforms. PRSG-5 and PRSG-6 will continue with this approach,
incorporating the transport sector and expanding the policy dialogue in the water sector as it relates to
ensuring the efficient operation of the newly created water utility, with greater focus of the policy
dialogue to ensure it supports the Government's vision to move toward a more integrated approach to
water resources management.

71.      Fourth, in response to a key lesson learned under the first series of PRSGs, to have a more
focused and lean harmonization and accountability framework, the Bank (through the PRSG
process) has worked with other budget support donors, under the leadership of Government to
develop a CPAF. The prior actions and indicators for the PRSG-5 and PRSG-6 are drawn from the
CPAF. In addition, the monitoring indicators and data sources will rely on the framework developed as
part of the CPAF.

72.      A key lesson learned regarding the support to GoR in the development of the CPAF, during
the PRSG-4 transition operation, is the importance of engaging early in the process and
maintaining close consultation with Government and donors. The design of PRSG-4 allowed space
for the dialogue and consultation needed to develop a CPAF that has the buy-in of the key stakeholders.
However, in a context of low capacity, the process of strengthening the CPAF and ensuring outcome
oriented policy actions is ongoing. The CPAF is a work in progress and this has been recognized by
Government and donors and a mechanism for review and improvement of the framework has been agreed
as part of the Partnership Framework for Budget Support (see Box 3). This highlights the need to make
room for country ownership and leadership of the CPAF.            To foster this country ownership and
leadership, the PRSG series may need to work with policy measures in the outer years that are not as well
defined in order to give ample opportunity for consultation, discussion and analytical work to support the
improved identification of measures.

                                   E. REFORMS SUPPORTED UNDER PRSG-4

73.      Achievements under PRSG-4 focused on key institutional and legal reforms related to the
monitoring framework for the EDPRS, as well as measures to support human capital development
and a reduction in the infrastructure constraints to growth. The PRSG-4 supported the development
of a national M&E framework for monitoring the EDPRS including the establishment of an M&E
secretariat in MINECOFIN and the recruitment of sector M&E staff. The operation also supported the
development of the Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF), which draws on the policy
actions and indicators elaborated at the national level for the EDPRS monitoring framework (see Box 2).
There was also support toward developing the strategic planning and budgeting framework in the
agriculture and transport sectors.



                                                   20

                         Box 3: The Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF)
What is it?
The Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF) consists of a set of indicators and policy actions selected from the
EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix and the Joint Governance Assessment (JGA). It forms the basis for budget support and
donors' joint assessment of the Government of Rwanda's performance in the implementation of the EDPRS. The CPAF is
complemented by the Donor Performance Assessment Framework (DPAF) which consists of a set of indicators and actions
drawn from international and national agreements relating to aid and its effective delivery, and forms the basis for government's
assessment of donor performance. The assessments would include performance of all partners (including non-budget support
donors) at both the aggregate and individual level.

The Process for Elaboration of the CPAF
The process of developing the CPAF (and the EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix, as well as the JGA) involved extensive
consultations and drew from the work of the existing 15 sector working groups (SWGs). Each SWG is chaired by a lead
Government institution and co-chaired by a Lead Donor. Initial consultations involved the development of sector policy and
results matrices with technical support and financing from DFID, World Bank and other Donors.

Development of the CPAF started in April 2008 and was based on the EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix that was done at the
national level for monitoring the EDPRS, and coordinated (over roughly a 12 month period) with each SWG of the EDPRS.
Simultaneously, a Joint Governance Assessment (JGA) was launched in March 2008 which summarizes GoR's performance in
the implementation of governance reforms in areas related to justice, voice and empowerment and accountability. The CPAF
was then derived as a subset of the national monitoring framework for the EDPRS supplemented with select indicators on
Governance from the JGA and the Government's PFM action plan. Indicators for the CPAF were agreed based on consultations
between Government and budget support donors and limited to a list of 18 strategic outcomes and 47 indicators (see Annex 2 and
Annex 4). To emphasize the commitment of all budget support donors and the Government, a MoU was signed in which all the
parties agreed to use the new reporting mechanisms (CPAF and DPAF) as part of a mutual accountability and harmonization
process aligning with the Paris Declaration.

Using the CPAF to Report on and Monitor EDPRS Achievements
Reporting of performance against individual CPAF indicators is led primarily at the sector level in advance of the Joint Budget
Support Review (JBSR). Sector performance reports are prepared in time for further discussion at the JBSR. The dialogue in the
JBSR is based on the joint assessment of progress in EDPRS implementation, including governance indicators and PFM reform,
using the CPAF as a single framework. For additional governance topics not covered in the CPAF an assessment is to be
reviewed based on the JGA annual review.

A forward-looking joint review will be held prior to the submission of a draft Finance Law or budget to the Cabinet in respect of
the following fiscal year. This review allows signatories to discuss proposed budget allocations, forthcoming activities in relation
to public financial management reforms, and the revision of the contents of the CPAF. This will be held in March in each budget
calendar year.

A backward-looking review of performance will be undertaken jointly within the four months that follow the end of the
Government fiscal year in question. During this review, signatories will discuss the progress and challenges encountered in the
implementation of the EDPRS in the previous year, reviewing budget execution and audited Government accounts of the year
before and value for money.

Process for Revision of the CPAF
Policy actions and targets of the CPAF are revised on an annual basis during the forward-looking Joint Budget Support Review.
Under exceptional circumstances, policy actions and indicators may be changed/ adjusted as long as they remain consistent with
the EDPRS and ongoing government policies and programs. The revised CPAF is agreed by all signatories and takes the form of
an annex to the minutes of the Review. Joint Reviews provide a forum for dialogue around the performance of both the
Government and its budget support partners and draws from the DPAF. It is undertaken following the same annual cycle as the
assessment of progress in the implementation of the EDPRS based on the CPAF.




                                                              21

74.      Table 6 below summarizes the key actions supported by PRSG-4. The PRSG-4 operation
supported reforms designed to lay the foundation for a comprehensive program to enhance the skills of
the labor force, and expand access to health services at the community level. Reforms in the eduation
sector focused on reducing the ratio of qualified teachers to pupils and developing a national TVET policy
that is responsive to the needs of the private sector. Reforms in the infrastructure sector focused on fully
incorporating into the Government's budget measures to improve water resources management for both
improved production activities and service delivery as well as irrigation and soil conservation. In the
financial sector, reforms focused on broadening the available financial instruments through the
establishment of a bond market and putting in place the legal framework for effective operation and
oversight of micro-finance institutions.

75.      In order to strengthen the focus of the second PRSG series on growth, continued Bank
support to the health sector reforms will proceed under the Community Living Standard Grant
(CLSG). Government has achieved important policy actions and milestones in the health sector, with
support from the PRSG series. PRSG-4 supported the adoption of the law governing mutuelles (prior
action for PRSG 4). Following on the above, a study on the sustainability of the mutuelle system has
been published, which provides input to the government's strategy for achieving universal coverage. A
milestone originally proposed for the PRSG-6, incorporation in District budgets of a subsidy to the
mutuelles, has already been achieved. At the same time, performance-based financing of facility-based
services was scaled-up in 2008 so that all of the over 400 public sector health centers in the country
receive support under this mechanism. Under the system, health facilities receive funding on the basis of
performance on a set of coverage and quality indicators, allocating the funds to staff remuneration as well
as maintenance and investment.       Before-and-after comparisons have shown substantial increases in
service utilization associated with the PBF system, and data is currently being analyzed from a
randomized impact evaluation that involved household and facility surveys. The related policy milestone
for PRSG-4 has been achieved ­ financing of US$ 0.90 per capita annually channeled through the PBF
mechanism to all participating health facilities.

76.      The Bank, through the CLSG, will continue to support the health financing policy,
emphasizing health insurance and performance-based financing, along with the community health
strategy, with the aim of expanding access to services. The PBF mechanism addresses supply-side
issues, largely through improving accountability, the expansion of mutuelles coverage, and reduced
demand-side constraints, particularly financial barriers to care. A third pillar of the government's strategy
to expand access to services, with particular emphasis on the rural poor in support to the VUP, is to scale-
up coverage of high-impact interventions delivered by community health workers, including a
performance-based incentive scheme. Relevant milestones were included in the PRSG-4 policy matrix,
including publication of the package of community health services (PRSG-4). Going forward, these
policies will be supported by a proposed Community Living Standards Grant (CLSG) series of
development policy operations.




                                                   22

                                            Table 5: Key Reform Measures/Achievements Supported Under PRSG 4

         V.     THE PROPOSED FIFTH POVERTY REDUCTION SUPPORT GRANT

77.      The proposed fifth poverty reduction support grant (PRSC-5) is the second in the second
PRSG series consisting of three annual operations supporting the implementation of the EDPRS, in
line with the 2008 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS). It continues to focus on two flagships of the
government's growth and poverty reduction agenda ­ Growth for Jobs and Exports, and Governance.

78.      The focus on the growth and governance aspects of the EDPRS aims to address the main
constraints to growth. The 2007 Country Economic Memorandum (CEM) identified three major areas
of constraints to growth in Rwanda (see Box 2): (i) poor water management; (ii) low use of modern
inputs such as fertilizers and improved seeds and lack of extension services in agriculture; (iii) the poor
condition of infrastructure ­ particularly electricity, transport, and water ­ that has limited the
development of the manufacturing and service sectors; and (iv) the low base of skilled labor, particularly
technical and managerial skills. In addition to the results of the CEM, the Diagnostic Trade Integrated
Study identified infrastructure costs as a major factor lowering the returns to trade and exports. It also
noted that improving productivity and supply was critical to improving exports. In addition, the recently
completed Investment Climate Survey (2008) indicated the above factors continued to pose a constraint to
growth and highlighted the importance of increasing access to finance for small and medium enterprises
(SMEs). Finally the attention to governance aspects recognizes the constraints posed by low capacity to
implement reforms and the importance of transparency and accountability for sustained growth.

79.      The operation is fully aligned to the Common Performance Assessment Framework
presented in Annex 2 which has been prepared with Government leadership in consultation with
development partners. In choosing indicators to align with the CPAF, the evolution from triggers to
prior actions for the PRSG-5 operation has been defined so as to ensure continuity of reforms and
progress toward meeting key prioritized outcomes. Furthermore, as a reflection of the substantive strides
achieved during the first wave of reforms that established critical laws and institutions including sector
strategies to implement the Government strategy, the PRSG-5 matrix (Annex 3) includes critical actions
related to the second generation of reforms that are now focused on the implementation of sector



                                                              24

strategies and the strengthening of the planning and budget preparation, execution and monitoring
function in the key sectors. Close consultation with Government and other budget support donors during
the development of the CPAF has enabled continuity in the reform program despite the fact that PRSG-4
was prepared as a transition operation toward full adoption of the CPAF. A smooth evolution from
triggers to prior actions has been possible because, in general, Government has completed all prior actions
and this has enabled a continuation in the reform program by taking from the CPAF the follow-on policy
measures and the next steps in the reform program.

80.      Prior actions have been selected on the basis of: (i) their importance in contributing to address
key constraint to the implementation of the intended reform and (ii) their alignment with the EDRPS
strategic objectives. The CPAF may be updated as necessary and critical updates will occur once a year
during the forward looking review of the budget. In that context, triggers for PRSG-5 have been modified
to ensure they are fully aligned to the CPAF. In particular, during consultations/discussions with donors
and government in the preparation of the PRSG-4, it was agreed that the operation would proceed without
the CPAF. Triggers defined for PRSG-5 reflect ongoing discussions held while preparing the CPAF and
indicate the continuity of the reform programs proposed by the Government and supported by the current
PRSG series. The evolution of triggers as defined in the PRSG-4 document to those in the PRSG-5
operation have been defined by two factors: (i) changes in the policy context which have influenced the
state of progress of reforms; (ii) the need to align with the CPAF which has been greatly facilitated by the
fact that many of the triggers/prior actions defined under PRSG-4 for PRSG-5 have been achieved. It is
therefore important to highlight and commend Government on their commitment and the substantial
progress in the reform program.

81.      Given the above context, support will continue for two uncompleted triggers for the PRSG-
5 which have been changed or modified to align with the CPAF--all other triggers have been
achieved as defined under the PRSG-4 operation. The two actions were: (i) signing of a performance
contract for the National Power Utility for 2009 to 2011, which includes targets on costs for generation,
cost recovery ratio, revenue and quality of supply; and (ii) the Rwanda Public Procurement Authority
(RPPA) is made operational and all procuring entities submit a draft procurement plan to MINECOFIN
after approval of the budget. In the case of the first action, the performance contract has been delayed due
to the need to first establish the power utility, the Rwanda Electricity Company (or RECO). This prior
action has therefore been changed to submission of the Law on Electricity and Gas to Parliament.
The second trigger was not completely achieved. The RPPA was established, but not all procuring
entities submitted a draft procurement plan to MINECOFIN primarily due to lack of incentives on the part
of the agencies to include the plans. MINECOFIN now plans to enforce the requirement by making it
mandatory in order for budget agencies to receive their budget allocation. As a result, the action to
submit the procurement plans has been kept as a PRSG-6 trigger. This action is critical to the effective
planning and implementation of projects and to ensure these are integrated into the budget (particularly
for those that are externally financed).

82.      The expected results at the end of the series are summarized in Table 10, in section VI and
include the following: In the area of governance, the reform program is expected to lead to substantial
improvements in public expenditure management as measured by both the PEFA indicator system and
Joint Governance Assessment. In the area of fiscal decentralization the reform program is expected to
reduce implementation constraints due to low capacity and weak institutions. Regarding civil service
reforms, the program is expected to produce (i) an improvement in organizational effectiveness and (ii)
strengthened public sector capacity for effective service delivery.

83.      In the area of service delivery, results to be achieved will cover the key sectors related to human
development as well as economic and infrastructure services. In terms of skills development, the focus
will continue to be on improvements in the quality of education. Towards this end, the PRSG series will



                                                     25

aim to increase the transition rates to upper secondary; and to develop technical and vocational education
and training systems that reflect the need of the labor market. For infrastructure, the series would lead to
an increase in access to electricity, an increase in the percent of classified road network in good condition,
and increased access to safe water and sanitation and its sustainable use. In the case of the financial
sector, the operation will contribute to increasing access to financial services to support micro-enterprise
development. Finally for agriculture, a substantial improvement in agricultural productivity is expected.

                                  A.    GROWTH FOR JOBS AND EXPORTS

84.      The PRSG-5 will continue to focus on key areas that have been identified as constraints to
growth.    These are discussed in this section: (i) Invest in Human Capital and Skills for Growth
education-- increase the number of well-trained teachers and make TVET private sector oriented; adopt
measures to promote development of science, technology and innovation (STI); (ii) improve economic
infrastructure; (iii) raise agriculture productivity and value-added exports; (iv) deepen and broaden the
financial sector.

(i)      Invest in Human Capital and Skills for Growth

Raise the Quality of Education by Increasing the number of well-trained teachers and make TVET
Private Sector Oriented

85.      The main challenge to developing a skilled and productive labor force that meets the needs
of the private sector continues to be the poor quality of education, and the need to improve
transition to secondary education. This has been a particular challenge given the substantial increases
in primary enrollment, requiring the absorption of large numbers of students and the need to close the
persistent gap in learning outcomes between girls and boys. More teachers with better qualifications are
needed to manage the higher primary enrollment rates and expanded demand for post-basic education,
thereby raising transition rates. In addition, the greater focus on science, technology and innovation (STI)
in the EDPRS will require an effective and well-functioning primary education system that is coherently
linked to a comprehensive and strategic post-basic education system.

86.      The government's response to the above challenges has been to focus on: (i) increasing the
supply and quality of teachers with the aim of reducing the pupil: teacher ratio; (ii) establishing a post-
basic education strategy focused on building the needed skills for the economy; (iii) an assessment of the
gap in needs for teachers and classrooms to inform teacher recruitment and development of infrastructure;
and an (vi) evaluation of the curriculum to make it more relevant to the needs of students and the
streamlining of subjects in primary and lower secondary education to make learning more effective and
focused on core subjects and skills relevant for the labor market in Rwanda.

87.      Toward these ends, the proposed second PRSG series is providing support to develop a
comprehensive strategic framework for post-basic education, including the development of a technical
and vocational education and training system that reflects the needs of the labor market and
implementation of the STI program. The prior action for PRSG-5 is the publication of the TVET
Policy. This has been achieved and approved by Cabinet. A TVET strategy is being developed in two
parts: (i) one for technical education that is being led by JICA; (ii) another for vocational training which
is being led by GTZ. The aim is to have a draft strategy that combines the two components. This will be
followed by a mid-term review to assess progress in 2009 and inform the costing exercise.

88.      The trigger for PRSG-6 will be to develop and cost the TVET strategic plan. Other actions to be
completed will include completion of an employers' survey to establish baseline information on
employment of TVET graduates. The related indicator will be the proportion of employers satisfied with
the performance of TVET graduates, and transition rates from basic to upper secondary education.

                                                                                                                                                                         EDPRS                                                    Government                                                                                                  established                                      on                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       RPPA                                                                                                                            procuring                                                                                                                           pr                                                                                                   after

Promote Science, Technology and Innovation


89.      To complement the development of a skilled labor force and facilitate the adoption and
adaptation of science, technology and innovation (STI), the growth agenda of the EDPRS calls for
the use of STI to improve productivity. This will be critical to the transformation of the economy from
one that is based on semi-subsistence agriculture to one that is based on the production of more
knowledge-intensive, higher value added goods and services. Given the high population density and
landlocked position of the country, the adaptation, adoption and application of the relevant technologies
will be needed to generate the level of productivity necessary to sustain growth.

90.      The Government is meeting this challenge through the development of the needed policy, legal
and regulatory framework as well as the governing institutions for putting in place a program to promote
science and technology.      A National Science, Technology and Innovation Policy has already been
approved that provides a framework for STI to contribute to the Government's broader development
goals, more specifically to diversify the economy, generate wealth via the expansion of higher value
added production, and create higher paying jobs. In addition, there is a Ministry of Science, Technology
and Scientific Research (MINSTR) which sits under the President's Office. Government is also in the
process of developing a legal and regulatory framework and governing institutions for science and
technology. Activities will include the identification and design of the institutional structures required to
implement the STI Policy, along with new legislation required to bring these institutions into effect. This
is being done in partnership with DFID.

91.      The PRSG therefore supports the development of the institutional structures required to
implement the STI Policy, ensuring strong links to the post-basic education strategic framework.
Specifically, the PRSG will provide support to Government in developing efficient and effective
arrangements for implementation of the recommendations from the Needs Assessment and Action Plans
(NAAPs) for the implementation of the STI Policy and ensuring its integration into sector plans by:

    (i)     Selecting the recommendations that will be implemented as a priority and that have high and
            demonstrable expected beneficial impacts; and are simple and straightforward enough to be
            easily and quickly implemented by a relatively inexperienced implementation unit.

    (ii)    Developing staffing and institutional arrangements for implementing the recommendations.
            Staffing and institutional arrangements will be described in detail in an operations manual.
            The aim is to have a small, flexible and efficient implementation team that is sufficiently
            equipped to not only implement the recommendations, but also ensure solid monitoring and
            evaluation so that lessons learned are taken into account in future activities, and results can be
            disseminated to relevant stakeholders.

    (iii)   Designing detailed implementation arrangements and procedures for these recommendations.
            The operations manual will contain the complete program design of all recommendations that
            are to be implemented during FY2010, including forms, eligibility criteria, evaluation
            processes, financing, etc.

    (iv)    Executing the initial stages of the implementation arrangements and ensuring sufficient
            budget is allocated to the prioritized activities enabling full incorporation into the budget by
            July 1, 2009.

92.      During the PRSG-5 implementation period, the focus is on providing technical assistance to
Government to prepare for full incorporation of STI in the CPAF in order to facilitate identification of
prior actions and triggers for the PRSG series.




                                                   29

(ii)    Improve Economic Infrastructure

93.     PRSG-5 continues to support reforms to address the policy, institutional and regulatory
environment needed to increase access of the population to infrastructure services while reducing
the cost of service provision. It complements the activities being financed through the key infrastructure
projects in the transport, urban infrastructure and water, rural water and sanitation, and electricity sectors.
An important aspect of the PRSG support to the infrastructure sector will be on the rigorous application of
the sector strategy to the MTEF to strengthen the budget framework. Also, the PRSG will support the
development of a harmonized donor involvement that has worked well for the social sectors. In line with
this, 3 outcomes (along with 4 related indicators) have been prioritized and selected from the CPAF: (i)
number of households and firms with access to electricity; (ii) MW of electricity generated; (iii) percent
of classified district road network in good condition; (iv) percent of water resources complying with water
quality standards certified by Rwanda Bureau of Standards (RBS). These are summarized in Table 10.
There is also discussion with Government to revisit some of the indicators in the water and private sector
development/financial sector to consider those that are more directly affected by the proposed policy
actions in the CPAF. These will be further discussed, and baseline information collected for those which
are agreed during the preparation of PRSG-6.

Increase Electricity Access and Supply

94.     Insufficient and expensive supply of electricity remains one of the main infrastructure
bottlenecks to growth, requiring more and cheaper sources of energy. Rwanda currently uses diesel
generators to supply a large part of the needed electricity. The goal, reflected in the CPAF, is to generate
130 MW of electricity by 2012, providing access to over 200,000 households. One of the projects
planned by Government to improve the situation is the construction of a hydro-electric power plant
at Nyaborongo, which is expected to supply 27.5 MW by 2011. To finance the cost of the project of
US $112.7 million over 4 years, Rwanda plans to borrow US $97.7 million from the India Exim Bank
with a grant element of 40 percent. The remainder of the amount will be financed through Government's
own resources. In the meantime, since October 2008, the first pilot of the Lake Kivu project has been
producing 1.3 MW of electricity. Further ongoing developments are, among others, the construction of
the Rukarara hydro power plant, as well as several micro hydro power plants, and the construction of
different electricity lines.

95.     Government is also proceeding with reforms to put in place the needed institutional and
legal framework to support efficient generation and distribution. Based on the recent law to separate
the water and electricity utilities, the Rwanda Electricity Company (RECO) and Rwanda Water Supply
Company (RWASCO) will be established in 2009. RECO will be responsible for bulk transmission and
distribution and retailing functions, while new large generation projects are planned for development by
the private sector that would sell to Electrogaz/RECO under a power purchase agreement or other
purchase arrangements that could be elaborated at a later date.

96.     Support under PRSG-5 and onward, in line with the priorities identified in the EDPRS, continues
to focus on improving the overall planning and expenditure framework, reducing the service cost and
introducing tariffs that reflect the cost structure of the national utility. The prior action for PRSG-5 is
the submission of the Law on Electricity and Gas to Parliament establishing a transparent regulatory
framework and an environment conducive to private sector participation in the sector, and clarifying the
roles and responsibilities of stakeholders in the sector. This action has been met. For PRSG-6, the
triggers will be the implementation of a cost reflective tariff for electricity generation--i.e. involving the
restructuring of tariffs to introduce tariffs that reflect the cost of generation and distribution with cross
subsidies for poor households through the application of a life-line block (yet to be determined).




                                                    30

Integrated and Sustainable Management of Water Resources

97.       In the water sector, the main issue is ensuring sustainable supply and improving access to
the population. This poses a constraint both through the availability of water for production purposes
(i.e. in industry and in irrigation or agriculture production), and also for safe water to prevent disease. In
particular, the low level of irrigation and terracing poses a significant constraint to agriculture
productivity. Given the various uses of water (i.e. for production, drinking and sanitation), Government
has moved to an integrated and sustainable approach to water resources management. Closer coordination
and collaboration of the key agencies charged with water supply and its use (i.e. MINIFRA which is
responsible for water infrastructure; MINRENA which now oversees the integrated management of water
resources including the formulation and implementation of policy; and the ministry of agriculture--
MINAGRI) is critical for the efficient management of water resources.                 The overall institutional
framework has improved coordination and harmonization in the sector, and has been strengthened
through the adoption of a law for the operation of the Rwanda Water and Sanitation Corporation
(RWASCO).

98.       The water sector management information system (WIS) would be instrumental to
coordination and planning in the sector. It would enable: (i) monitoring the programs of various
service providers to limit gaps in sevice; (ii) provision of information for projecting future needs and
assessing trade-offs between competing demands. The Water Ministry has put in place a policy of
encouraging donors to concentrate their efforts in specific regions of the country and views
decentralization of spending as key to successful delivery of service in the sector. Districts are and will
be increasingly responsible for executing large portions of budgetary allocations. The WIS would enable
government to monitor the activities and programs of various government agencies, donors, and other
stakeholders to ensure there are no gaps in service delivery. Finally, to achieve faster economic growth
and reduce the vulnerability to weather shocks (arising from ineffective water management), sufficient
water resources need to be available for productive uses; and the water sector information system would
play a critical role in assessing this availability.    Data from the WIS would enable government to
determine the trade-offs for optimal water use for economic growth, and is critical to developing a sound
approach to the integrated management and planning of water resources.

99.       Reforms to enable the operationalization of RWASCO will also be a key area of priority.
This involves implementation of the provision of the law creating RWASCO by: (i) concluding a
performance contract between the Ministry and RWASCO Board of Directors defining the power, rights
and responsibilities of each party to facilitate supervision of the utility; (ii) putting in place arrangements
for effective management through the conclusion of a performance contract between the Board of
Directors and the management of the utility with well defined performance indicators; (iii) completion by
RWASCO of the needed institutional arrangements to enable hiring of staff including the preparation of
the book of accounts and establishing appropriate tariff setting mechanisms and guidelines.

100.      The PRSG will provide assistance in putting in place the institutional arrangements and
guidelines and work with Government to outline the critical reforms needed to implement the tariff
(which could form a basis for future policy triggers/milestones).             The water sector management
information system (WIS) will cover water resources and both rural and urban sanitation. The objective
is to develop and provide a sound and credible data base on the water sector, and facilitate efficient
monitoring and evaluation of operations in the water sector. The institutional structure is in place, the
design of a comprehensive WIS has been completed, along with the data management structure and the
staff that will operate the information system have been hired and trained. What is needed now is to
populate the databases related to water and sanitation and water resources, including use of water.
Establishment of the system will begin with the water and sanitation sector.




                                                     31

101.     The prior action for PRSG-5 is to establish a management information system for the water
and sanitation sector including a national inventory of water and sanitation infrastructure, to
facilitate effective water resource management. This has been achieved and the overall design and
institutional arrangement for the system has been validated by the relevant stakeholders. The next action
is to operationalize the WIS, to adopt a process for collecting, analyzing, reporting and dissemination of
information generated from the system, and to develop the various databases for the sector (rural and
urban water supply and sanitation, irrigation water use and water resources potential and use) in an
integrated manner. Establishing and operationalizing the WIS will be critical to identifying bottlenecks in
water availability and gaps in service delivery

Increase Rural Road Access by Improving the Condition of the Classified District Road network

102.     The main problem related to access pertains to a need to put in place a framework for
regular maintenance and rehabilitation of the road network that is fiscally sustainable, particularly
in rural areas. As a result, Government reforms have focused on improving road maintenance and
rehabilitation as well as the overall framework for strategic planning and budgeting in the sector.
Government has recently completed a Road Maintenance Strategy that also includes a District/Rural Road
Maintenance and Decentralization Strategy.          The strategy specifies the institutional framework and
financing sources along with procedures and standards for classifying and maintaining the road network.
It also outlines the roles and responsibilities of the central government and Districts in road maintenance.

103.     The Government has also launched the process for a Public Expenditure Review to more
deeply examine the key constraints to improve road maintenance planning and prioritization,
harmonize implementation of road works on classified and non-classified roads, and design a more
strategic approach to cost recovery and funding policies for road maintenance. The PER analysis
for this sector will therefore examine the spending and financing patterns of the Road Maintenance Fund
(RMF) to determine how well spending is aligned with the EPDRS and sector objectives and explore
ways to improve the efficiency of spending. This work will also include technical support to project
evaluation and choice of investment to support the development of the sector's investment plan and
MTEF.

104.     The prior action for PRSG-5 is the adoption by Cabinet of a Maintenance Strategy
(including the framework for maintenance and decentralization of District/Rural roads). It includes
a framework for the financing and operationalization of road maintenance, clarifying the roles and
responsibilities of the Central Government and Districts in road maintenance. This action was achieved
in December 2008. For PRSG-6, the triggers will be the signing by Districts of 3 year Multi-Annual
Output and Performance Based Road Contracts with at least 2 additional contractors. Expected outcomes
at the end of the PRSG series will be: an improved strategic and expenditure framework to support
increased investment in the sector, an institutional framework for decentralized road maintenance with
emphasis on rural roads, an increase in the percent of the classified road network in good condition.

(iii)    Raise Agriculture Productivity and Value Added Exports

105.     Investments in irrigation and water management, research and extension, increased access
and use of fertilizers and improved seeds, and the adoption of appropriate farming technologies
and practices are needed to sustain agriculture growth and reduce the dependence on rain fed
production. The proposed PRSG will complement support provided through the Rural Sector Support
Project and by the Belgian Cooperation. In particular the RSSP is focused on promoting client oriented
applied research; investments to promote soil and water conservation technologies; strengthening farmers'
associations and cooperatives; soil and water conservation; and building the policy, capacity and
institutional frameworks to promote increased access and use of inputs including seeds and fertilizers and



                                                     32

the adoption of appropriate technologies. The Belgian Cooperation is taking the lead to support actions in
the areas of extension services.

106.     In addition, Government is working with its development partners to develop a coherent
agricultural sector development strategy aimed at raising the (currently) very low levels of input
use, and minimizing the impact of external shocks, particularly among smallholder subsistence
producers who make up the majority of the farming population. Government is scaling up existing
pilots of the CIP, particularly with the distribution of fertilizer and improved seeds-- only 2 percent of
households accessed fertilizers under the Government's pilot Crop Intensification Project (CIP) last
season. Scaling up the CIP pilots should help to maintain and increase current levels of domestic food
production and protect consumers from the rapidly rising cost of imported foods. Irrigation development,
which the Bank is actively supporting, can be expected to reduce dependence on rainfall and drive
agricultural productivity growth over the medium to long term. IFAD is providing financing of $35
million for the CIP in Kirehe. The IFAD financed component will explicitly rely on and emphasize
intensification and integration of crops and livestock and the use of appropriate agricultural technologies
and practices.

107.     The PRSG focuses on the key areas of support related to reforms to strengthen soil and
water conservation and irrigation, as outlined in the PRSG-4 program document.                   It is also
supporting institutional reforms to develop a private sector led fertilizer distribution system. The prior
action for PRSG-5 is the completion of feasibility studies on watershed management in at least four
(4) out of the thirty-four (34) sites identified for watershed management and terracing under the
Land Husbandry, Water Harvesting, and Hillside Irrigation Program, and including a technical
assessment of such pilot activities and mapping of areas requiring protection through watershed
management and terracing. For PRSG-6 the trigger will be to develop and implement an action plan to
promote emergence of a private sector-led fertilizer procurement and distribution system. The outcome
indicators are the percent of farmers using improved fertilizer (both chemical and organic) increases from
a baseline of 12 and 7, respectively, to targets of 20 percent (chemical) and 17 percent (organic) by end-
2010; and for the area of land sustainably managed against soil erosion and made productive through
irrigation to increase from a baseline level of 40 percent to 60 percent in 2010.

(iv)     Broaden and Deepen the Financial Sector

108.     While much has been accomplished in terms of laying the groundwork for financial
broadening and deepening, the challenges remain daunting.               A household survey, completed in
December, 2008 by FinScope, provides the first comprehensive demand-side assessment of usage of
financial services in the country. By far the most significant barrier to banking in Rwanda is linked to
low incomes. Eighty-three percent of the unbanked population indicates they do not have enough money
left after covering daily living expenses to place money in an account. The largest barrier to borrowing
cited was the fear of being unable to meet repayment requirements. These findings highlight the fact that
just over half of the surveyed population had an income of under FRw 5000 (US $9.20) per month. The
top reasons cited for having a bank account were savings (68 percent), followed by credit (50 percent).
Even among those who bank, cash transactions dominate, reflecting the underdeveloped payments
system.




                                                   33

Retention                       (MINECOFIN, MIFOTRA, MINEDUC,                                                  and ministerial structures for
                                MININFRA, MINITERE,                                                            optimal performance within
                                MINISANTE)                                                                     fiscal limits




                                                                     34

109.     The low level of rural and agricultural finance represents a constraint to realizing the
Government's objective of raising agricultural productivity. While agriculture represents 40 percent
of GDP and 80 percent of employment, it constituted just 5.4 percent of credit to the economy in 2007. It
should be noted, however, that agricultural credit received just 1 percent of loans in 2001, and has since
expanded over 700 percent (versus growth in credit of 156 percent overall over the same period).
Reasons for the relatively low level of rural credit include: (i) clients are unable to provide adequate
collateral for loans, in part because the legal framework for secured transactions is weak; (ii) the absence
of products widely used elsewhere to finance agriculture, such as warehouse receipts, forward contracts,
inventory financing, leasing and factoring; (iii) rudimentary value chain financing which does not give
banks control over payments; (iv) lack of expertise and experience in agronomy and agricultural
economics among commercial banks which gives rise to perceived high risk in investing in the sector and
poor product development for rural finance; (vi) the preponderance of sight deposits in the funding of
micro-finance institutions (MFIs), and the absence of refinancing or liquidity facilities to enable them to
tailor lending to crop cycles or investment needs of farmers.

110.     In response to the above challenges, Government is putting in place a policy on
microfinance and a related law. The policy defines different types of microfinance institutions, with
graduated capital and prudential requirements depending on their size, whether or not deposits can be
taken from the public, etc.          It also sets forth oversight and reporting arrangements.               The policy is
generally sound and in line with international good practice.

111.     In the case of rural finance, the Government plans to continue with a second phase of its
Rural Investment Facility which has been instrumental in improving access to rural finance. The
second Rural Investment Facility (RIF-2) aims to improve incentives to investment in the agricultural
sector in Rwanda.3 In line with the EDPRS priority given to growth in agricultural productivity, the
Government is pursuing a multi-pronged approach to growth in the agricultural sector, where access to
finance has been identified as a key constraint.4 The Government is therefore adopting measures to
improve rural access to finance in Rwanda through products and services that help investors and bankers
to manage risks and to better serve the rural population. These measures include the piloting of innovative
rural finance products (e.g. leasing, value chain finance) and capacity building for farmers, their
organizations and financial service providers through a pipeline agricultural World Bank operation.5
These activities are being developed in full collaboration with efforts of other partners to provide a
coordinated response to the development of sustainable rural finance. It is acknowledged, however, that
these measures will take some time to take effect and that there is a critical short term gap in incentives for
productive investment in agriculture that can be aptly filled by a second and final phase of the RIF.
Annex 9 provides an overview of the operation of the RIF, as well as the technical terms and conditions
of its implementation. These are well informed by lessons from the first Rural Investment Facility (RIF
1). Achievements under RIF 1 are summarized in Box 4 below.

112.     The modernization of the payment systems has also been launched: a National Payment
Council has been established, and a National Payment Strategy published by BNR. The World Bank is
supporting BNR in introducing a Real Time Gross Settlement system and Automated Clearing House,
which are expected to be operational by 2010. In parallel, the Government and SIMTEL are working


3
 The total RIF 2 fund endowment will be roughly USD 10 million, of which USD 9 million from IDA under the PRSG-5 and
about USD 1 million ( RWF 500 million) from monies retained from RIF-1, which have been kept by BNR in a special account.

4
 World Bank. 2007. Promoting Pro-Poor Agricultural Growth in Rwanda: Challenges and Opportunities. Agricultural Policy
Note (IBRD: Washington DC).

5
 The pipeline Land Husbandry, Water Harvesting and Hillside Irrigation (LWH) operation which has a rural finance sub-
component supporting the piloting of innovative products, financial literacy and capacity building.




                                                            35

towards the introduction of an electronic payment card system, possibly linked to the national identity
card.

                               Box 4: Achievements of the Rural Investment Facility

Results from the first phase of the RIF indicate that it can substantially contribute to promoting productive
investment in the sector. Under RIF 1, a total number of 4,296 loans received grants totaling US $10.4 million for a
total of fully US $31.3 million in `RIF loans'. Although most RIF recipients were groups and individuals with prior
access to finance, an independent evaluation of RIF-16 found that 77.5 percent of RIF-financed agricultural activities
would not have been undertaken without the RIF facility. Furthermore, the same study found that RIF-financed
activities created an average of 26 permanent jobs per project, which is a substantial contribution to the development
of rural based employment.        Finally, RIF-1 contributed to the rapid expansion of agriculture credit by the
commercial banking sector witnessed over the period 2002-2007. Over that period, the BNR reports that lending to
the sector grew from 1.7 to 5.4 percent of all private loans outstanding in Rwanda, representing cumulative lending
of roughly US $60 million to agriculture. Note that over the same period, RIF loans alone accounted for almost half
that amount.


113.      Despite the above progress in reforms in the financial sector, it remains weak, and much
remains to be done to build capacity and professionalism in the industry if it is to play a significant
role in providing financial services to a broad cross section of urban and rural Rwandans. The
Government, along with the World Bank and several other development partners are providing support to
strengthen the sector (prudential oversight, training, MIS, refinancing lines, audit, etc.).

114.      The PRSG series will continue to support Government efforts to improve access to financial
services (with a focus on rural finance), and promote the development of capital markets and long-term
financing instruments. In that regard, the prior action for PRSG-5 is the signing of an MoU between
BNR and MINAGRI to support investments in the rural sector under the second Rural Investment
Facility (RIF 2). This action has been completed. The proposed trigger for PRSG-6 will focus on the
adoption of appropriate legal and regulatory frameworks for the national payments system, credit bureau,
and secured transactions. These are critical areas in the Governments reform agenda as outlined in its
Financial Sector Development Plan for strengthening the financial system and increasing credit access.

         B.     IMPROVE ECONOMIC GOVERNANCE AND DEVELOP IMPLEMENTATION CAPACITY

115.      Substantial progress in PFM reforms has been achieved; however, low capacity remain the
main constraint to the progress in reforms. In particular, capacity as it pertains to technical know-how
and having in place the appropriate systems and institutions continue to be an area of weakness for PFM
reforms. Recent assessments indicate that the main areas of weakness pertain to having skilled and
professional PFM specialists, adopting a management information system, low capacity in procurement
methods, and the need for the appropriate incentives in civil service reforms to build the capacity of staff
and improve retention.

116.      The areas of support and main outcomes are drawn from the CPAF as follows: (i) develop an
enhanced the public financial management system; (ii) strengthen capacity for procurement methods; (iii)
Deepen the budget and fiscal decentralization reforms; (iv) adopt civil service reforms to build skills,
incentives and retention; (v) develop the system for monitoring and evaluation.




6
 Triodos Facet. 2007. Evaluation: Rural Investment Facility. AB Zeist: Triodos.




                                                           36

(i)     Develop an Enhanced Public Financial Management System

117.    Although there has been substantial progress in PFM reforms, a number of challenges and
issues remain to be addressed. The Government recently completed an analysis of the strengths,
weaknesses, opportunities and threats (SWOT) for the implementation of the PFM Reform Strategy
which identified a number of key priorities which Government is currently addressing: (i) the need for an
integrated information system to strengthen; (ii) the need to develop comprehensive and costed strategies
for the other key sectors of the EDPRS (this exist currently only for education and health); (iii) low
capacity overall for financial management and accounting specialists. Table 8 summarizes the results of
the SWOT exercise (see also Annex 7). The Public Sector Building Capacity Program (PSCB) has
supported the development of the PFM Action plan through a basket fund. The PRSG series focuses
support on the implementation of the Integrated Financial Management Information System (IFMIS).

                       Table 8: SWOT Analysis of PFM Reforms and Strategy in Rwanda
