                                                      37

118.     Given the SWOT analysis and Government priorities as outlined in the PFM Action Plan,
the prior action for PRSG-5 is the completion of development of the PublicBooks software. The
completion of the software will greatly facilitate the improvement of budget preparation, reporting, and
accountability in budget agencies, and increase transparency.          The triggers for PRSG-6 will be
PublicBooks pilots are completed and rolled out to all budget agencies and integrated with the Payroll
system. A key outcome will be the ability of each budget agency to submit completed sets of financial
statements for each year beginning in 2009 as stipulated in the OBL.

(ii)     Strengthen Capacity and Transparency of Procurement Methods

119.     Government has made substantial progress toward strengthening the legal and regulatory
framework for procurement, and now needs to strengthen capacity to implement the reforms.
Following the adoption of the procurement law and establishment of the Rwanda Public Procurement
Authority (RPPA), the GoR now needs to adopt the related regulations and standard bidding documents.
The low capacity within the procuring entities is currently the main challenge to continued reforms. Due
to the capacity problem it is necessary for the RPPA to be involved in procurement operations by
undertaking prior review functions above certain thresholds.

120.     Aside from establishing the legal framework and accompanying reforms, the Government
has put in place institutions to promote increased transparency in procurement. Independent review
panels have been set up and made operational at the national and district levels, according to the provision
of the Law (five members, out of which three are from the private sector and civil society organizations).
During the first semester 2008, twenty six (26) appeals (compared to 29 for the last semester 2007) were
filled, out of which 42 percent led to a change in the contract award (compared to 50 percent). Bidders on
public procurement contracts now have access to independent recourse to appeal contract awards. In line
with this achievement, Government is now publicly publishing the independent review of appeals (which
was previously an internal Government document). In recognition of progress made in this area, this
measure is included as a prior action under PRSG-5. On Fraud and Corruption cases, fourteen (14) cases
were received in 2008, out of which two (2) were convicted of corruption, but ten (10) are still pending to
be tried. In addition, the RPPA website already publishes a list of debarred firms. However, procurement
plans, contract awards, sanctions are not yet being published and enforcement in this aspect is still very
weak.

121.     The PRSG supports the prioritization of actions identified in the draft capacity building
work plan to enable the development of a two-phase strategy. In the short term, this strategy shall
comprise the dissemination of the new procurement regulations (Law, Standard Bidding Documents,
RPPA functions, procurement audits, appeals mechanisms, etc.) to the various stakeholders involved in
procurement operations (procurement officers in the procuring entities, RPPA staff, public decision-
makers, private sector representatives and civil society organizations); the objective is to ensure (i) a
proper implementation of the new regulations, (ii) a greater transparency and competition in the
procurement transactions and (iii) an efficient spending in public funds. In parallel, and in the medium
and long term, this strategy shall aim at developing a curriculum that will cover all aspects of
procurement including training of lawyers, managers, decision makers leading to a degree and/or
professional designation. The partnership agreement shall also ensure that over a defined period of time,
trainers will be drawn from a pool of national and well trained professionals. The RPPA will publish
these procurement plans on its website.

122.     One indication of developed capacity will be the ability of procuring entities to prepare and
publish their procurement plans. This would also facilitate integration of externally financed and
capital spending into the recurrent budget. In addition, the Procurement Code stipulates that all procuring
entities must prepare and publish a procurement plan to indicate the timing, methods and various steps of



                                                   38

the process as well as its expected completion date. To facilitate implementation of the procurement code
and consolidate the results from the capacity building exercises, it will be critical to ensure that all
procuring entities are able to comply with these instructions.

123.     Given the above, the prior action for PRSG-5 is the publication of the 2008 annual report of
the independent panel addressing appeals by contractors of public procurement decisions. The
trigger for PRSG-6 will be the submission of a procurement plan with budget proposals to MINECOFIN,
by all procuring agencies, and the publication of these procurement plans on the RPPA website. This will
facilitate improved transparency and help with the integration of externally financed projects in the
budget.

(iii)    Strengthen Implementation of Budget and Fiscal Decentralization Reforms

124.     The focus of budget reforms has been on strengthening performance based budgeting and
more closely linking the medium term expenditure framework (MTEF) and the annual budget
ceilings. Measures to adopt performance based budgeting aims to ensure that the MTEF structure enables
monitoring of the Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EDPRS) and sector policy
implementation.    In line with this, the economic classification of the budget has been revised in
accordance with the main areas of focus and programs of the EDPRS. Also, the criteria for priority
expenditure has been updated and aligned to the EDPRS to facilitate the monitoring of EDPRS
implementation through the Annual Budget. These changes are being reinforced with training programs
on the new MTEF structure and budget preparation, to support the planning units at the central and local
government levels, and in particular to provide support toward training in costing.

125.     At the decentralized level, since the initiation of fiscal decentralization reforms in 2006,
there has been a steady increase in the absolute and relative amount of transfers to local
governments (see Table 9). Transfers have increased from 8.8 percent of total budget to an estimated 13
percent in 2008. However, there is the issue of a multiplicity of earmarked grants that constrain efficient
planning and autonomy of the districts, and strains capacity.

                                        Table 9: Decentralized Budget

                                                                   2006       2007      2008
                  Decentralized Budget                            35734      64640      80766
                  Total Budget                                   404738     527971     623226
                  Decentralized as % of Total Budget                8.8        12.2      13.0

                  Source: Budget Laws, Ministry of Finance, Government of Rwanda, 2008.



126.     Reporting and improved autonomy for the Districts in planning will be greatly improved
through the simplification of the allocation formula and the streamlining of the multiplicity of
earmarked transfers. In order to increase District autonomy in the face of limited own-revenues the
study recommends that other sectors follow the agriculture sector model in the management of earmarked
transfers. Specifically, district budgets have 37 EDPRS defined activity budget lines which have separate
grants. However, for the agriculture sector, multiple lines refer to one grant or transfer. This gives
districts more discretion and autonomy during the budgeting phase to allocate resources across the various
budget lines. The study also highlights the need to further clarify the division of roles between local and
central government in service delivery within each sector. This is critical for strengthening the autonomy
and capacity of the districts and will be an area of continued technical support during the course of the
PRSG series.




                                                      39

127.     Government has outlined priority areas of reform based on a recent review of the existing
grant allocation system which found that there is still scope to strengthen the definition of roles
between central government and districts for service delivery. Government plans to undertake an
assessment of the current block grant system to inform revision of the transfer formula. In addition, an
assessment of Districts' own resource earning potential will be undertaken to inform the design of the
transfer formula since districts are currently heavily dependent on the center for financing. As part of this
effort, all Districts will complete a statement of revenue and expenditure.

128.     The above reforms will have to proceed gradually over time given capacity constraints and
limited local revenue sources. In the meantime, as the capacity is developed in these areas the focus of
this series of PRSGs is on improving reporting on the current level of district transfers and using lessons
learned to inform the continual development of capacity and prioritization of reforms, and the definition
of precise policy actions to be monitored in the CPAF. The trigger for PRSG-6 will be to adopt and
operationalize a comprehensive 5-year capacity building strategy for local government.

(iv)     Adopt Civil Service Reforms to Build Skills, Incentives and Retention

129.     The main issues related to the civil service are as follows: (i) underdeveloped core systems
related to management information, monitoring and performance management systems--which are
currently being developed by MIFOTRA; (ii) understaffing of central ministries in key policy areas; (iii)
existing organizational structures adopted by most ministries that are not aligned with their functional
responsibilities. As a result, ministries have resorted to recruiting temporary staff, project financed staff
or expatriates, which is a necessary interim solution. However, an approach toward building a more
sustainable long-term capacity and skills acquisition is needed.

130.     A long-term approach, to build and retain capacity, requires attention to incentives and the
career path for the civil service. To this end, a recent survey of 46 "leavers" prioritized the following
factors: (i) salary and benefits (cited as the primary reason by 50 percent of those surveyed; (ii)
management problems (raised by 45 percent of the respondents, including individuals "not getting on"
with the boss); (iii) lack of career prospects and possibilities of promotion (mentioned by 40 percent of
respondents). In addition, a pay study noted that pay levels are not necessarily lower than in the private
sector. However, private sector employers generally offer greater upward potential in remuneration.

131.     To address the problem of skills and retention, as well as clarify the functional structure and
coordination across government agencies, Government plans to undertake the following actions:

    ·    Establish an internship program for current and recent graduates to introduce them to the civil
         service and provide a pool of potential new recruits for Government

    ·    MIFOTRA to elaborate manuals and procedures for a performance management system and all
         PRSG ministries to adopt processes for performance management, train staff and use manuals
         developed

    ·    MIFOTRA to establish clear systems, mandates and roles for the relationships between
         Ministries, districts, agencies and other stakeholders (`framework documents') and all PRSG
         ministries are to produce ministerial instructions/decree that clarifies the division of labor and
         oversight arrangements with districts, their agencies and other stakeholders

    ·    MIFOTRA to agree with all PRSG ministries on staffing levels and ministerial structures for
         optimal performance within fiscal limits and all PRSG ministries to adjust structures and staffing
         levels for optimal performance within fiscal limits.



                                                    40

132.     Support under the PRSG will complement the technical assistance being provided under the
Bank's Public Sector Capacity Building Project (PSCBP) to support skills development and staff
retention in the civil service, and strengthen coordination of functions and structures. In addition, triggers
under the PFM section are focused on developing the IFMIS and integrating this with payroll and HR
which will complement the areas of support related to civil service reform and facilitate the availability of
information to enable rigorous audits of MIFOTRA. As part of the restructuring exercise started in July
2008, all ministries and districts have submitted proposals to readjust functions across different
government levels and revisit organizational structures and staffing levels. The PRSG series will continue
to provide support to Government in this area and strengthen the civil service component of the CPAF. In
the meantime, PRSG-6 will support the process leading up to an agreement between MIFOTRA and all
central ministries on staffing levels and ministerial structures for optimal performance within fiscal limits.

(v)      Monitoring and Evaluation

133.     A monitoring framework for the EDPRS along with a Common Performance Assessment
Framework (CPAF) has been developed under Government leadership and in close collaboration
with Donors. The CPAF outlines a subset of indicators and policy actions around which all budget
support donors have agreed with Government to focus. In addition, Governance indicators have been
included into the framework and are based on the PFM action plan. Furthermore, a central M&E
Secretariat has been established at MINECOFIN and 16 M&E officers have been hired who will be made
part of the organigram of Government. These officers will be attached to Ministries and Provinces.

134.     Government has hired M&E officers for each ministry. The aim is for MINECOFIN to
coordinate and provide support to ministries who will have their own M&E officers.                      Sector
monitoring matrices need to be updated and aligned with the M&E tools being developed by
MINECOFIN. Finally, the coordination mechanisms between MINECOFIN and sector ministries will
need to be developed.

135.     A capacity building plan to support these officers is being developed by HIDA and
MINECOFIN.         The plan will combine multiple tools such as training sessions on specific issues,
community of practice, training on the job, etc.        A Road Map that outlines the work program for
developing the system and institutional processes will be developed to facilitate alignment of donor
funding. In addition, there has been continued progress in the institutionalization of the citizen report
cards with the completion of community score cards in key sectors and institutional mechanism for
linking result to Imihigo contracts are being developed.


                              VI. OPERATION IMPLEMENTATION

                                   A.    POVERTY AND SOCIAL IMPACTS

136.     Overall, the reforms and measures to be supported under this operation are geared toward
improving access of rural households to services to support their income generating and
employment activities and therefore no adverse impacts are foreseen in this aspect. Poverty and
social impact analysis will be used to identify measures to strengthen the aspects of the operation that
most promote inclusive growth. Specifically, to gain a deeper understanding of the dynamics that have
defined the pattern of poverty incidence, an analysis of the growth poverty linkage will be used to
examine ways of further refining and targeting interventions to ensure there are greater growth benefits
accruing to the more vulnerable and poor segments of the population. Additional studies are being
undertaken and used to strengthen the design of the capitation grants in education (per capita transfers to
school facilities to provide greater incentives for hiring and retaining teachers, and the provision of school
materials). The education country status assessment will examine disparities in educational attainment


                                                    41

between boys and girls and will inform development of the strategy for improving access for both girls
and boys. In addition, construction of a multidimensional poverty index to assess impacts of transport
development initiatives on poverty is planned as part of the second phase of the development of the
national strategic transport master plan.

137.     The Government also remains committed to understand the distributional impacts of key
policy reforms and economic actions. For example, a quantitative analysis, (using quasi-randomized
methods), of smallholder access to improved inputs in the tea sector finds that there is differential access
to fertilizer between men and women. The reason for this differential access is tied to access to micro-
credit and assets for borrowing. Government has therefore included in its design of the private sector-led
fertilizer distribution system a component to target fertilizer vouchers to small holder wheat and maize
producers, a significant proportion of which are women. In the case of electricity reforms, a poverty and
social impact analysis of the previous increase in the flat tariff showed that because access rates to the
network are very low among the poor, the share of implicit subsidies that prevailed before the increase in tariff
was very low and provided little benefit to the poor. There is a plan now to restructure the tariff to both cover
costs of the utility while also putting in place cross-subsidies for poor households. This will be done through
the application of a life-line block. Lower tariffs for households in the poorer income brackets will increase
the uptake rates of the electricity roll-out program, making it affordable for a large proportion of
households and enabling them to connect and consume electricity. Analysis completed so far shows that
affordability will be the main barrier to achieve Government's target of 35 percent access to electricity (as
outlined in the Vision 2020). Further in depth analysis is planned on the precise structure of the lifeline
and the implications for covering costs and ensuring equitable access for poorer households.

138.     In general, the assessment of the poverty and social impact of the measures proposed by the
EDPRS and supported by the PRSG is carried out in the context of Rwanda's EDPRS monitoring system
and in particular the household living conditions and demographic health surveys that analyze, among
other things, poverty trends and dynamics every five years. The surveys which cover the entire country
provide a rich source of information on household socio-economic characteristics, including consumption
expenditures, employment, and access to social services, etc. The surveys will be complemented by
annual integrated poverty assessments to enable mid-course adjustments towards reaching identified goals
and targets set over a 5 year period.

                         B.      IMPLEMENTATION MONITORING AND EVALUATION

139.     Monitoring and evaluation arrangements will continue to rely on government arrangements
with the aim of strengthening government capacity and institutions. The Government has developed
in close collaboration with partners, including the Bank, a results and performance framework integrated
into the planning and budgeting processes for monitoring the EDPRS (see Annexes 4 and 5). The
integrated results framework/monitoring system consists of three components: a National Results and
Policy Matrix; a Common Performance Assessment Framework; and a Development Partners'
Assessment Framework.          An institutional framework for monitoring in which responsibility for the
overall monitoring of the EDPRS rests with MINECOFIN's Strategic Planning Unit has been established.
In addition, the Budget Monitoring and Reporting team reports on spending of the budget and related
outputs. This team also ensures that the sector spending plans are incorporated into the macro-MTEF,
and budget. The Bank will work closely with these two units to monitor spending and outputs achieved
under the PRSG series.

140.     To improve monitoring systems, the Bank has supported the Government's efforts to build
quality and institutional capacity. Alongside the PRSG, the Bank is implementing grants from the
Trust Fund on Statistical Capacity Building and the Belgian Poverty Reduction Partnership Trust Fund




                                                      42

aimed at enhancing statistical capacity. The Bank's ongoing investment projects each have an M&E
component that supports both the project and the relevant sectoral ministry.

141.    The monitoring and evaluation of the PRSG series draws from the CPAF which was
finalized in December, 2008. Table 11 summarizes the expected outcomes and related indicators and
targets. Monitoring of these indicators will rely on the Government system. Definition of each indicator
along with measurement and data source has been outlined by the National Institute of Statistics. The
Bank will therefore monitor the key indicators and the overall CPAF in close collaboration with other
budget support donors.

                 C.    GRANT AMOUNT, DISBURSEMENTS AND ACCOUNTS AND AUDIT

142.    A single-tranche grant of SDR 53 million (USD 80 million equivalent) would be made
available upon effectiveness, which is expected in March 2009. The proposed grant will follow the
Bank's disbursement procedures for development policy operations. Grant proceeds will be disbursed
against satisfactory implementation of the development policy program and not tied to any specific
purchases or be subject to procurement requirements. Once the Bank's Board approves the grant and it
becomes effective, and at the request of the Recipient, IDA will disburse the proceeds of the grant into an
account designated by the Recipient that forms a part of the country foreign exchange reserves at the
Banque Nationale du Rwanda. The Recipient shall ensure that upon the deposit of the grant into said
account, an equivalent amount is credited in the Recipient's budget management system, in a manner
acceptable to IDA. The Recipient will report to IDA on the amounts deposited in the foreign currency
account and credited in local currency to the budget management system with an indication of the
exchange rate applied. IDA reserves the right to request an audit of said account. If the proceeds of the
grant are used for ineligible purposes (i.e. to finance goods or services on the standard negative list), as
defined in the Financing Agreement, IDA will require the Recipient to promptly upon notice from IDA,
refund an amount equal to the amount of said payment to IDA. Amounts refunded to IDA upon such
request shall be cancelled. The administration of this grant will be the responsibility of the Ministry of
Finance and Economic Planning.

                                       D.     FIDUCIARY ASPECTS

143.    The public financial management system is reasonably adequate to support the PRSG. In
addition, a key focus of this operation is related to continued support to strengthening the Government's
public financial and expenditure management and procurement systems. Areas of support under the
PRSG have been summarized in the previous section. Assessments of the fiduciary aspects are largely
based on results from the PEFA indicate that public financial management and procurement systems have
been improving steadily in line with government commitment to reform, (as outlined in its Financial
Accountability Review and Action Plan), and the dialogue between the Government and the donors has
been constructive. Fiduciary assessments are also based on results from recently completed PERs in the
education, health, agriculture, and water sectors, 2004 HIPC Assessment and CPAR, as well as the 2005
CFAA. In addition, the National Bank of Rwanda (NBR) was subject to a safeguards assessment in the
context of the PRGF arrangement approved on June 12, 2006. The update assessment proposed
recommendations to address continuing vulnerabilities in the external audit and financial reporting areas.
The implementation of these measures is being monitored under the Fund program. Finally, the Bank is
undertaking a policy driven technical assistance PER to provide capacity building support to Government
in expenditure analysis and monitoring.

                                    E.    ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS

144.    Under Operational Policy 8.60, on Development Policy Lending, the Bank is required to
determine whether specific country policies supported under the operation are likely to cause significant
effects on the country's environment, and, in the event of such likely effects, assess country systems for
reducing any such adverse effects and enhancing such positive effects. In the event of significant gaps in



                                                   44

the analysis, or shortcomings in the country systems, the Bank is required to identify how such gaps or
shortcomings would be addressed before or during program implementation, as appropriate.

145.    Following these policy requirements, specific country policies supported by the PRSG 5 are not
likely to cause significant effects on Rwanda's environment, forests and other natural resources. On the
contrary, any likely adverse effects are expected to be minor and manageable through the existing Bank
framework in place for the PRSG 5 areas of support.

146.    In the current PRSG series, such minor environmental effects may arise through measures to
support irrigation, watershed management and terracing, rural road maintenance, and fertilizer
distribution. An extensive Environmental Assessment and Social Analysis undertaken during PRSG 1
remain relevant in this regard. As with the first series of PRSGs, the current series (PRSG 4 to 6), will
rely on two areas to address potential environmental concerns: (i) continued strengthening of the overall
framework for environmental management in Rwanda; and (ii) environmental management assessments
undertaken in the context of other Bank projects.

147.    There continue to be improvements in the framework for environmental management in
Rwanda over the last decade resulting in noticeable improvements in the institutional framework
during the last five years. Since 2004, MINIRENA has had the responsibility for the environment,
mines, land, forest, and water resources. For policy formulation and implementation, MINIRENA relies
on a number of specialized public agencies including REMA (environmental agency), REDEMI (mining),
and the National Land Center (land use planning and delivery of titles). Over the last four years,
MINIRENA has secured the adoption of several pieces of legislation by the national assembly, including
laws on forests, land, water, environment, and mining that will improve the management of natural
resources. However, MINIRENA is facing tremendous challenges and many operational constraints. In
particular, the lack of adequate staffing both at the central and district level is a noticeable hindrance to
effective policy implementation and coordination. The capacity constraint seems particularly severe at
the district level where most of the responsibilities for sectoral policy implementation are located. This
second series of PRSGs will support continued capacity building to strengthen the key agencies charged
with environmental management. This will complement the program of small grants for environmental
capacity building provided by UNEP that is being used to build in a framework for environmental
assessments in key ministries. Support to strengthening the institutions for environmental management
also is taking a much longer view that has involved the incorporation and mainstreaming of improved
environmental stewardship into the medium-term expenditure framework of MINIRENA. More work is
needed to incorporate budget allocations in a medium term framework that translates the objectives of the
ministry's 2005-2010 Strategic Plan into measurable actions and results on an annual basis. Appropriate
resources will need to be allocated to well-targeted capacity building activities at the central and district
level, and to cross-sectoral technical support aimed at addressing the environmental management needs of
the second and subsequent series of PRSGs. The focus will be on a long-term sustained support to
building capacity to address environmental concerns in the implementation of the EDPRS.

148.    Environmental management assessments undertaken in the context of other Bank projects
will also help to address any potential environmental concerns for the proposed policy areas of the
PRSG.      In the case of irrigation and marshland development, Government has developed the
environmental framework for marshland development. Policies to support the development of irrigation
schemes will require adequate resources to control the incidence of water-borne diseases, pollution of
surface and groundwater by agrochemicals, water-logging and salinization of soils, and population
resettlement. In that context, the PRSG will rely on completed environmental assessments for the Rural
Sector Support Project which has supported the development of marshlands. Further assessments will be
completed in the context of the proposed Lake Victoria Project and the Land Husbandry, Water
Harvesting, and Hillside Irrigation (LWH) Project which is a comprehensive land-husbandry, water-



                                                   45

harvesting and hillside-irrigation initiative for commercialized and professional agriculture currently
under preparation. In the case of support to development of the fertilizer procurement and distribution
system, the focus is on building institutional capacity for improved fertilizer distribution. Currently, the
total level of fertilizer use is so small and the amounts to be stimulated are projected to be barely 40
percent of the country's total needs. Therefore, the quantity of fertilizer distributed is not expected to be
large enough to have significant adverse environmental impacts while having substantial positive impacts
on productivity. In addition, as part of the RSSP 2, training will be provided to communities in proper
handling and application of these materials as part of local capacity building. Finally, the road
maintenance strategy includes a framework for addressing environmental assessments in line with the law
and regulations of the Rwanda Environmental Management Agency. Specifically, maintenance contracts
are required to include clauses to ensure HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention, environmental protection
and labor standards.

149.    In sum, while the proposed operation is expected to have no significant adverse effects on the
environment, country systems have adequate capacity, and appropriate arrangements have also been made
through Bank work, as outlined above, to address any such minor effects that might arise. The operation
therefore complies fully with the requirements of OP 8.60.

                                    F.    RISKS AND RISK MITIGATION

150.    There are four main risks potentially associated with the program as follows:                      i)
macroeconomic and financial sector risk; ii) regional/country risk; ii) program risk; and iv) fiduciary risk.

151.    Macroeconomic and Financial Risk. This is rated moderate to low risk given the GoR's record
in macroeconomic management. Overall GoR's record has been rated as satisfactory as evidenced also
through the satisfactory completion of reviews under the PRSG. Risks to the program could arise through
continued reductions in world commodity prices that compromise export earnings coupled with a
reduction in grants as the world recession deepens in donor countries. To mitigate the potential balance
of payments risk Government has reduced expenditures and increased reserves. The effects of the world
recession are not yet evident in the economy. Should these effects become substantial, the Bank would
consider providing supplemental financing. Government will continue its policy of identifying areas for
contingent spending should more external resources become available. It will also continue to protect
priority spending from any in overall spending. Finally, it will continue with measures to expand the tax
base and improve the efficiency of the tax system. Mitigation of this risk is achievable as long as GoR
continues to implement reforms to increase investment to support growth.

152.    In terms of the large injections of liquidity that has been evident in the past, Government policy
actions have demonstrated the commitment to employ policies that maintain the flexibility of the
exchange rate while sterilizing the excess liquidity. Regarding any appreciation of the exchange rate and
the likely effects on exports, it will be critical to put in effect policies to improve the supply response,
ease the constraints to productivity and support increased absorption. This is the main area of focus of the
PRSG operation.       In addition, Government has demonstrated through its management of previous
injections of liquidity into the economy, its commitment to use market based instruments to ensure that
inflation is contained and any potential exchange rate appreciation is well managed. Furthermore, the
level of gross reserves in months of imports has been between 5 and 6, providing adequate import
coverage and underlining the government's commitment to prudent macroeconomic management.

153.    However, there may be a need for Government to take on some concessional loans, on a selective
basis, to enable the necessary investments to generate growth. The World Bank and the IMF will
continue to support the Government in managing macroeconomic reform and investing in infrastructure
development to ensure continued growth and productivity. In the context of the low income country debt



                                                    46

sustainability framework, the Bank and Fund will continue to monitor the evolution in Rwanda's debt
indicators which are currently substantially below set thresholds.

154.     Regional/Country Risk.       Instability in the Great Lakes Region continues to be a risk to
Rwanda's economic stability and to the consolidation of development progress. Success in addressing
this risk requires the strong engagement of the governments in the region as well as the international
community. The signature on November 9th 2007 of a Joint Communiqué between the Governments of
Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo with the objective of resolving the question of the
presence of Rwandan combatants on Congolese territory, in a collaborative manner, is an important step
forward. In January 2008, the Government of DRC signed a peace accord with over 20 militia groups
operating in the country. At the international level, both the United Nations and the African Union have
continued to support the establishment of peace in the region. UN Security Council Resolution 1804,
adopted in March 2008, exhorts the FDLR and all Rwandan armed rebel groups to lay down their
weapons and return to Rwanda. The recent high-level meeting in Nairobi in November 2008, which
reiterated the importance of implementing the above agreements, is further evidence of the diplomatic
efforts of the international community to find a lasting solution. The Tripartite Plus Joint Commission
continues to work toward identifying measures to counter the negative forces operating in the region.
Following the flare up of fighting in Eastern DRC in late 2008, some budget support donors who
constitute a small share of overall budget support suspended their budget support due to their uncertainty
over Rwanda's compliance with the underlying principles of the Budget Support Partnership Agreement
Framework, related to the promotion of peace and security in the region (Article 18 of the partnership
MoU signed between GoR and Budget Support donors in April 2008).              Since then these donors have
begun discussions with the Government with a view to resolving the issues of contention. On January 20,
2009, the Governments of DRC and Rwanda begun a joint military operation to disarm the FDLR, within
the framework of an accord signed between the two countries on December 5, 2008. This agreement has
been supported by the EU, as a sign of improving relations between the two countries. The joint initiative
demonstrates the willingness of both Rwanda and the DRC to find a lasting solution to the problems of
instability in the region. If successful, this could mark an important breakthrough in achieving greater
peace and stability for the region

155.     Currently, Rwanda's internal security and political situation remains stable.              However
continued effort is needed to address the remaining political effects of the 1994 genocide. Constraints
surrounding the Gacaca system have given rise to contentions both by victims and perpetrators of the
genocide, and highlighted the need to strengthen ongoing efforts to build a strong judiciary. Government
efforts to continue to open the political space also need to continue. As part of this effort, a law on NGO
groups has been revised in line with international experience.

156.     Program Risk. Predictability of donor funding, the ability to mobilize donor funding and debt
sustainability continue to be the main program risks. DFID's three-year rolling program within an overall
10-year commitment provides a good model for enhancing the long-term predictability of donor funding.
There has been a general move toward budget support, and the recent suspension of disbursements by a
few budget support donors (see paragraph 178 above) is not foreseen to have any substantial adverse
effects on the program due to the small share of the amounts. However, the recent global slowdown could
pose a risk to the past increasing trend to budget support for the country. Improvements in frontloading by
donors will help the GoR to plan and implement its budget in a more sustainable manner. In the short-
term, the Bank has worked to help the GoR access the Catalytic Fund for Africa. The Bank could also
consider supplemental financing should there be any indication of a significant shock to the balance of
payments. Over the long-term, the GoR will need to continue to focus on mobilizing additional grant
financing, which is critical if the GoR is to remain within prudent debt sustainability limits.




                                                   47

157.    Fiduciary Risk. The rapid decentralization undertaken by the GoR has heightened potential
procurement and public financial management risks since only limited accompanying fiduciary measures
were included. However, the GoR has committed to accelerating its efforts to address these risks. The
GoR is drafting an easy-reference guide for procurement, along with a technical assistance "hotline" for
procurement officers. It is also accelerating the implementation of the Rwanda Expertise Scheme that is
training accountants, to be deployed at decentralized levels, in the Rwanda public accounting system, and
sponsoring the best among them for professional accountancy qualification. Furthermore, this series of
PRSGs is supporting the adoption and implementation of a comprehensive 5-year capacity building
strategy for local government, which includes measures to strengthen public financial management at the
local level.

                                                  79

                      Annex 4: The EDPRS Implementation and Monitoring Arrangements

1. Formation of Implementation Working Groups7

          The Sector Working Groups (SWGs), which were used to elaborate the EDPRS will be grouped into eight
Implementation Working Groups (IWGs) to correspond to the priority areas of the EDPRS and to link with the
seven technical platforms of Rwanda Economic and Social Development Council (RESC). IWGs are forums to
coordinate between sectors and between government and development partners, to discuss policy issues and monitor
implementation. Each IWG is chaired by one of the Ministry SGs, co-chaired by a donor representative, and
supported by a technical secretariat, based in the Lead Ministry. Each IWG will comprise the stakeholders from
related sector working groups. Through being more closely aligned to EDPRS priorities, this leaner structure should
facilitate the process of monitoring.

          This, however, does not mean that SWGs will cease to exist. The SWGs will operate as usual. Their role
will be to update the sector strategies in line with their logical frameworks and thereafter to conduct annual Joint
Sector Reviews and produce Public Expenditure Reviews. They will also ensure that their respective M&E
frameworks are operational on the ground. However, for coordination, alignment and harmonization purposes and
joint up thinking for implementation and monitoring, SWGs will combine forces under their respective identified
priority areas and work as IWGs.

          MINECOFIN is represented at all platforms of RESC and also all IWGs; DPU will therefore act as the link
between these two bodies. Figure 1 below shows the proposed structure of the EDPRS institutional monitoring
framework. Cabinet will provide the policy direction. Forum of Secretaries General (SGs) will coordinate the eight
implementation working groups (IWGs).

          The EDPRS Central Monitoring and Evaluation Secretariat will monitor information and analysis carried
out in the IWGs. The M&E Secretariat will be supported by the DPU Focal Points and EDPRS M&E Specialists for
different sectors. The Secretariat will forge close links with NISR, which collects and compiles data at central and
local levels to monitor the EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix. Capacity of NISR will be built through a five year
capacity building programme after undertaking a comprehensive skill audit. MINECOFIN will hold regular co-
ordination meetings and agree a clear division of responsibilities with the NISR.

          The Forum of SGs will take into consideration views from development partners through the Development
Partners' Coordination Group (DPCG), which formally monitors the Common Performance Assessment Framework
(CPAF) which has been prepared as a sub-set of the larger EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix. The DPCG is linked
to the IWGs through development partner membership of the IWGs.

          Local government is represented through Province Steering Committee (PSC) representation in IWGs. The
role of the PSCs is to coordinate District implementation and maintain strong channels of communication between
IWGs and Districts, to ensure that IWG priorities are reflected in the work of local government and that local
implementation bottlenecks are highlighted to be resolved by the IWG.

          At the political level, monitoring and evaluation will be carried out through a single EDPRS review
framework that stresses both domestic accountability and accountability to development partners. Domestically, the
EDPRS progress will be reviewed by the EDPRS Annual and Biannual Progress Reports, the steer for which will be
provided by the Forum of SGs, drawing on the work of the IWGs and other reviews and evaluations.

          The EDPRS Annual Progress Report (APR) will be published in April each year, drawing on the Joint


7
 The above write-up is taken from the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning document "The Institutional Framework of
EDPRS Monitoring".




                                                           80

Sector Reviews, Public Expenditure Reviews and District Imihigo evaluations, completed in February . It will
review progress against the annual performance indicators and actions in the EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix for
the previous 12 months. A detailed and harmonized reporting system will be developed for IWGs, SWGs and
districts by June, 2008 taking policy actions and targets of national policy and result matrix into consideration.

          Building on existing systems, the APR will be submitted firstly to the DPCG for consultation prior to
submission to the Forum of SGs. In addition, a Biannual Progress Report will be produced in September, for GoR
consumption only, reviewing interim progress against the annual policy actions in a given year. The Joint Sector
Reviews will be supported by regular Public Expenditure Reviews, Citizen Report Cards and Community Score
Cards.

          The Annual Progress Report will also make clear recommendations for any revision of targets and policy
actions in the EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix, as deemed appropriate. Discussion and agreement of necessary
revisions for the Common Performance Assessment Framework (CPAF) will be made during the April Joint Budget
Support Review.

2. The process to implement the institutional framework for EDPRS M&E

          The National Results and Policy Matrix will be the main basis for monitoring EDPRS at the macro level. It
will be aligned with all SWG M&E Frameworks which will be further refined and developed following a common
universal format. This in turn will help the sectors and DPU to select key indicators, which will then be incorporated
with district imihigo contracts. Technical inputs will be provided by NISR to monitor the performance at national,
sector and district levels.

          The Joint Action Development Forum is responsible for overseeing the progress made on the district
imihigo contract indicators and conducting Joint District Reviews.         The Joint Sector Reviews (JSR) will be
conducted at the end of February every year. The progress made on JSR and Public Expenditure Review (PER) will
be the main basis for sectors to update their M&E frameworks. IWGs will be responsible for feeding information
from the updated M&E frameworks to CMES who in turn will check and update the National Policy and Results
Matrix.

          Based on the above, the secretariat will be responsible for preparing progress reports which will be
submitted to the DPCG for review. Once reviewed, reports will be sent to the Forum of Secretaries General by the
CMES for approval. Reports will finally be submitted to the Cabinet Secretary by the Secretary General's Forum
for approval and policy guidance.

3. Roles and Responsibilities of the Implementation Working Groups (IWGs)

        Each IWG will comprise a number of sectors (including line Ministries, government agencies and
development partners), and will be supported by a Secretariat. The main role of the IWGs is to ensure cross-sectoral
coordination in implementation and discuss policy issues. This contrasts with the role of the sectors/line Ministries,
which prepare the Joint Sector Reviews, conduct Public Expenditure Reviews, establish M&E systems and develop
their sector-wide approaches (SWAps).

Objectives:

          The Implementation Working Groups' (IWGs') key function is to assist in the monitoring of EDPRS
implementation, with a focus on ensuring cross-sectoral coordination. Each IWG will have an associated Secretariat,
located in the Lead Ministry and reporting to the Secretary General of the Lead Ministry, which will be responsible
for ensuring smooth functioning of the IWG and coordinating the production of key outputs including the biannual
reports on progress with the EDPRS matrix. The Secretariat will be supported technically and financially by the
donors intervening in the IWG under coordination of the Lead Donor.

The Cross-Cutting Issues (CCIs) Working Groups' key objective is to attend the IWG meetings and ensure CCIs are



                                                        81

represented in the IWG discussions and actions.

          Specific tasks and outputs: The specific tasks of the IWGs are to meet quarterly to discuss policy issues,
cross-sectoral coordination and produce the biannual progress reports. The IWG Secretariats will provide technical
support to the fulfillment of these objectives, and brief the IWG on key developments.

          Biannual progress reports: the IWG will produce biannual progress reports on relevant sections of the
EDPRS Results and Policy Matrix. The first report, due in March of each year, should report on progress towards
indicators and policy actions in the previous year. The second report, due in August of each year, should report on
progress towards the fulfillment of policy actions in the current year. These reports will be communicated to
MINECOFIN/DPU for compilation into the EDPRS Annual and Biannual Progress Reports.

          Results and Policy Matrix updates: based on the annual and biannual reviews of progress, the IWG will
discuss and recommend necessary revisions of targets and policy actions. These recommendations will be discussed
and ratified by the Forum of Secretaries General and Cabinet.

          Quarterly meetings of the IWG: the Lead Ministry of the IWG will organize quarterly meetings of the IWG,
to discuss policy issues and cross-sectoral coordination. The lead Ministry should ensure that all government
institutions and development partners listed are invited to the IWG or sub-group meeting. It should contact the
following additional organizations to ensure they are informed in time to send representatives to every IWG
workshop: -The five Province Steering Committees + Rwanda Association of Local Government Authorities
(RALGA) -International NGO and local NGO platform organizations -Rwanda Private Sector Federation -Faith
based organizations -Prime Minister's Office -MINECOFIN (Development Planning Unit)

          It is the responsibility of the lead donor to assist the Lead Ministry with the coordination of the IWG and to
ensure the donor community is fully represented in every IWG meeting. Donors should also provide technical
support to the Secretariat, as well as ensuring sufficient financial resources are available to support the process.
Each IWG Secretariat will, in advance of the IWG meetings, produce and circulate quarterly briefings prior to the
IWG meeting, on key developments relevant to the IWG. The briefing should be no longer than 2 pages. It can
include progress on key projects, issues of multi-agency coordination, harmonization and alignment with
development partners etc. The Secretariat will also produce and circulate minutes of the meetings.

Mechanisms of communication with stakeholders:

          The IWG will normally communicate with stakeholders through the quarterly meetings and quarterly
progress reports. The lead donor should assist the Lead Ministry and Secretariat in maintaining track of key
developments on the donor side.




                                                          82

                          Annex 7: Progress in Ongoing Budget and MTEF Reforms

158.    Government has already accomplished several key reforms to address some of the issues
identified in the SWOT exercise. In September 2006, the Organic Budget Law (OBL) was promulgated and
Government launched the development of an Integrated Financial Management System (IFMIS). The IFMIS
(or SmartGov) is an integrated suite of software packages that include two key modules-- BudgetMaster and
PublicBooks. BudgetMaster is an application used to prepare and execute the Government budget, including
commitment control, cash management and central treasury payment system. PublicBooks is currently under
development and is the general ledger module that collects information from BudgetMaster for the purposes of
public accounting. Simultaneously an integrated personnel payment information system (IPPIS) for efficient
payment of salaries, payroll records and control is being developed by MIFOTRA. The IPPIS will interface
with SmartGov for data sharing and processing. This will lead to improved control of the payroll and more
accurate salary payments.

159.    Following the enactment of the OBL in 2006, a number of instruments were put in place for its
implementation, namely: (i) Financial Regulations which became operational in February 2007; and (ii) the
Manual of Financial Management and Accounting which was published in May 2007. Among the actions
taken to operationalize these instruments, include the design and dissemination of new reporting formats for
both central and local governments, and the launch of a series of sensitization and training workshops. These
measures provide the framework for substantially improved financial reporting at all levels of government. It
also continues to raise awareness about the importance of PFM in general, and has consolidated the existing
reforms and provided the legislative framework for the production of the first ever consolidated government
financial statements that were produced in May 2007.

160.    Aside from production of the consolidated accounts, there is an ongoing exercise to produce
monthly, quarterly and annual financial reports for all government entities including local governments.
Work to consolidate the accounts at the local government level is also ongoing through the Accountant
General's Office. In addition to the work on the consolidated accounts, there is a capacity building program
for public accountants and internal auditors. The program aims to create sustainable capacity for public
accounting and internal audit in Government Institutions. The training program has a short term aspect (skills
enhancement) as well as a long-term aspect (for professionalizing these staff). In line with this effort the law
establishing the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Rwanda (ICPAR) was adopted by Parliament on
December 20, 2007.

161.    In terms of budget oversight, BudgetMaster generates the total amount spent by each District
but is unable to disaggregate by category to allow functional and economic analysis. In addition, work
has been initiated in the design of a public accounting system (PublicBooks) that would form part of an
integrated financial management information system (IFMIS). Pilot testing of PublicBooks and with roll out
to budget agencies is expected to begin in the first half of 2009. In the meantime, Sage Pastel (which is being
used while the accounting module is developed) and PublicBooks (the accounting module currently under
development) are likely to be run in parallel in 2009. An oversight User Group has been formed and will be
led by the Accountant General's Office to provide input into the development and piloting process.

162.    To improve coordination of PFM reforms and provide a framework for sustained financing, and
address the issues summarized in the SWOT analysis, Government recently completed a PFM Strategy
and Action Plan. The PFM reform strategy and action plan identifies the priorities for reform, provides a
more structured and sequenced framework in which to carry out specific reform activities, guides the
mobilization of resources (including external funding), and improves coordination as well as sustainability of
the reforms aimed at strengthening the PFM systems. The PFM action plan was revised and posted on the
Government's website in September 2008.         The plan focuses on reforms in a range of PFM areas and
functions--budgeting, accounting and auditing, procurement, reporting and external oversight.           GoR is
currently in the process of costing the plan and establishing a basket fund to finance the plan. Over the next



                                                     86

year, Government will be focused on establishing the secretariate and steering committee that will oversee
implementation of the PFM action plan. The aim is to have in place by the end of 2009 all governance and
implementation mechanisms to support the PFM action plan, along with the financing mechanisms.

163.     Further reforms to strengthen spending efficiency will require establishing a closer link between
the recurrent and development budget through the economic classification of capital expenditures.
Actions have been taken toward this end within the new Chart of Accounts and the 2008 budget will be
prepared with a revised economic classification. In addition, there has been a modification of the budget
format to enable an integrated presentation and allow for the partial integration of programs and sub-programs
in the development budget. However, extra-budgetary expenditures remain an issue in some sectors.

164.     The next steps in the integration of the development and recurrent expenditures will involve
developing a framework for monitoring of extra-budgetary expenditures. The objective is to design a
system of capturing and monitoring of own resources and expenditures outside the budget system. Although
information on extra budgetary resources is being progressively collected, there is now a need to put in place a
system to ensure maximum compliance from agencies. There is also an initiative through the ICT department
to capture and integrate the development budget execution reports simultaneously into Smartgov. Efforts to
train and sensitize users on these issues are on-going.

165.     In the case of fiscal decentralization, reporting on transfers is increasingly critical to address. In
order to facilitate reporting, Government supported adoption of the BudgetMaster software which enabled
Districts to report on spending in 2007. However, the classification system (under the BudgetMaster) does not
allow functional and economic analysis of District expenditure. This will need to be addressed to facilitate
improved reporting by Districts

166.     Continued strengthening of capacity will be needed to implement the next stage of procurement
reforms given progress reforms related to the legal and regulatory framework. Some capacity building
activities have already been undertaken with: (i) the recruitment and staffing of procurement officers in all
procuring entities with 116 now on board as of March 08; (ii) a DG Market training provided to procurement
officers throughout 2008, (iii) a two-week induction training for these staff conducted in the first quarter 2008,
by the Rwanda Institute of Administration and Management (RIAM); (iii) a two-month post graduate diploma
in purchases developed by RIAM and attended mainly by civil servants (but which still lacks proper
procurement trainers), (iii) a MOU signed in April 16, 2008 between the RPPA and the School of Finance and
Banking (SFB), which lay out the bases for a future collaboration, and (iv) the design of a capacity building
work plan, adopted by the Task Force and submitted for discussions and inputs from the Human Resource and
Institutional Development Agency (HIDA). The next step is to consolidate these reforms aimed at building
sustainable capacity and institutions for procurement reforms.

167.     To further consolidate procurement reforms, Government is focused on quickly strengthening
the capacity of procuring entities and their staff. Although there have been several short and limited
training sessions, the overall procurement capacity remains very low. Until recently, there was no strategic
plan for procurement capacity building.       The procurement Task Force has adopted a strategic plan, for
finalizing the Code of ethics for staff handling procurement matters. Discussions are still ongoing on the
publication of procurement audits.




                                                     87

                                                     88

          Annex 9: Overview, Terms and Conditions of the Second Rural Investment Facility (RIF 2)

Overview
From the December 2007 evaluation of the first Rural Investment Facility (RIF 1),8 from the
implementation completion report (ICR) for the Rural Sector Support Project (RSSP), from various
assessments and technical missions carried out during the design process, and from other MINAGRI-
initiated surveys on the common interface between production, processing and agricultural finance, a
number of lessons regarding the design of the Second Rural Investment Facility (RIF 2) come to the fore:

     (i) As banks and MFIs continue to regard medium- to long-term investment lending as risky, their
          interest in investment financing could continue to be positively influenced by a grant component
          for such investments, such as that proposed by the RIF 2;

     (ii) The link between grant support and loans by the financial sector for investments should be
          maintained, although the grant/loan ratio in RIF 2 should be updated to reflect current
          Government priorities for the sector (see Table 12 below);

     (iii)The use of long-term funds should be restricted to investment loans, and there should be no grant
          support for working capital. The financial sector today is capable of funding working capital
          loans - which have a repayment period of less than one year - from their own resources. All
          financial institutions regard working capital loans as less risky than investment loans, and have
          fewer restrictions on funding of these loans.

     (iv) Agricultural marketing activities are very profitable, and do not in any way require or justify
          grant support;

     (v) As access to finance is one of the objectives identified for the project, no investor should receive
          grant support more than once and efforts should be made to include poor households with viable
          investment projects;

     (vi) Only financial institutions with a functional management information system (MIS) capable of
          monitoring portfolio at risk should be eligible for participation under the component. Without
          such MIS, they cannot guarantee that they will at all times be in a position to submit regular
          reports on financial performance.

These lessons learned, and others, were fully incorporated into design and implementation technical
parameters informing the following terms and conditions for the RIF 2.

Terms and Conditions

1. Eligible Categories of Investment under RIF 2

The following categories of investment define eligibility for RIF 2 grants (see also clause 2 below): (1)
Primary agricultural production; (2) Processing of agricultural production; and (3) Agricultural support
services, including seed production. The allocations and ceilings governing these categories of investment
are as follows (also summarized in Table 12 below):

     ·    Under the category of "Primary agricultural production", the lower and upper limits per project
          are RWF 1 million and 50 million respectively. Loans up to RWF 10 million will receive a grant
          of 25 percent of the investment loan, while loans above this will receive 20 percent of the
          investment. At least 45 percent of the Facility will be used for this category.


8Triodos Facet. 2007. Evaluation: Rural Investment Facility. AB Zeist: Triodos.




                                                    89

    ·    Under the category of "Processing of agricultural products", the lower and upper limits per
         project are RWF 2 million and 150 million respectively. Loans up to RWF 50 million will receive
         a grant of 25 percent of the investment loan, while loans above this will receive 20 percent of the
         investment. A maximum of 35 percent of the Facility will be used for this category.
    ·    Under the category of "Agricultural support services, including seed production", the lower and
         upper limits per project are RWF 2 million and 150 million respectively. Loans will receive a
         grant of 15 percent of the investment loan. A maximum of 20 percent of the Facility will be used
         for this category.

                      Table 11: Grant Support Parameters for Investments under RIF 2

                     Minimum      Maximum     Potential grant amount per project Maximum      Ceiling for all
                     project size  project                                         support       projects
                                     size                                        per project
  Type of project
                                                                                  (in FRw      In % of total
                                                    (in % of total loan for
                           (in FRw mn)                                              mn)         RIF 2 fund
                                                         investments)
                                                                                               endowment
  Primary
                                                25 for loans up to FRw 10 mn         2.5
  agricultural           1           50                                                             45
  production                                  20 for loans above FRw 10 mn           10

  products                                      20 for loans above FRw 50 mn         30
  Agricultural
